{"sim": 0.8509804010391235, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9559845", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wral.com", "title": "WRAL.com", "id": "18458"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://wwwcache.wral.com/asset/business/2017/08/16/16885017/media_9030087c94a94ea7aaf4e427d9601485-DMID1-5bs9j2jsy-520x360.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 430, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 440, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2712, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 2723, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.wral.com/fed-officials-split-in-july-over-inflation-worries/16885017/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:31:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over inflation worries :: WRAL.com", "uri": "710530744", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:31:00Z", "time": "20:31:00", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Federal Reserve policymakers were worried last month about inflation, but for two opposing reasons.\n\nOne group of Federal Reserve policymakers felt inflation was falling too low and argued for caution in raising interest rates. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory.\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.\"\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December at the earliest. The latest reading of traders' expectations shows less than a 50-50 chance of a December hike, according to the CME Group. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2 percent goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2 percent inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,\" meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.\n\nThe Fed's next meeting is Sept. 19-20.\n\nIn an interview Monday with the Associated Press, William Dudley, head of the Fed's New York regional bank, said that the market's view that the announcement about bond reductions would come in September was \"reasonable.\"\n\nDudley said he did not expect much of an impact on financial markets because the action had been well-telegraphed by the Fed, unlike the \"taper tantrum\" incident that occurred in 2013 when bond rates temporarily spiked when markets were caught by surprise by comments from then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke that the Fed was contemplating moves to reduce the size of its monthly purchases of bonds.\n\nThe Fed's balance sheet has soared five-fold -- to $4.5 trillion -- since the summer of 2008, just before the financial crisis erupted. The increase came as a result of purchases the Fed made of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. The purchases were designed to put downward pressure on long-term interest rates as a way of giving the economy an extra boost after the Fed had cut its short-term rate to a record low near zero.", {"sim": 0.8509804010391235, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9556589", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "963"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 435, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 445, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2717, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 2728, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/F/FEDERAL_RESERVE_MINUTES?SITE=CAANR&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:07:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over inflation worries", "uri": "710522114", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:37:00Z", "time": "18:37:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve policymakers were worried last month about inflation, but for two opposing reasons.\n\nOne group of Federal Reserve policymakers felt inflation was falling too low and argued for caution in raising interest rates. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory.\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.\"\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December at the earliest. The latest reading of traders' expectations shows less than a 50-50 chance of a December hike, according to the CME Group. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2 percent goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2 percent inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,\" meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.\n\nThe Fed's next meeting is Sept. 19-20.\n\nIn an interview Monday with the Associated Press, William Dudley, head of the Fed's New York regional bank, said that the market's view that the announcement about bond reductions would come in September was \"reasonable.\"\n\nDudley said he did not expect much of an impact on financial markets because the action had been well-telegraphed by the Fed, unlike the \"taper tantrum\" incident that occurred in 2013 when bond rates temporarily spiked when markets were caught by surprise by comments from then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke that the Fed was contemplating moves to reduce the size of its monthly purchases of bonds.\n\nThe Fed's balance sheet has soared five-fold - to $4.5 trillion - since the summer of 2008, just before the financial crisis erupted. The increase came as a result of purchases the Fed made of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. The purchases were designed to put downward pressure on long-term interest rates as a way of giving the economy an extra boost after the Fed had cut its short-term rate to a record low near zero.", {"sim": 0.8509804010391235, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9550597", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "963"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 435, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 445, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2578, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 2589, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/APFN_FEDERAL_RESERVE_MINUTES?SITE=ORCOO&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:30:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over inflation worries", "uri": "710506029", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:27:00Z", "time": "18:27:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve policymakers were worried last month about inflation, but for two opposing reasons.\n\nOne group of Federal Reserve policymakers felt inflation was falling too low and argued for caution in raising interest rates. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory.\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.\"\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2 percent goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2 percent inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,\" meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.\n\nThe Fed's next meeting is Sept. 19-20.\n\nIn an interview Monday with the Associated Press, William Dudley, head of the Fed's New York regional bank, said that the market's view that the announcement about bond reductions would come in September was \"reasonable.\"\n\nDudley said he did not expect much of an impact on financial markets because the action had been well-telegraphed by the Fed, unlike the \"taper tantrum\" incident that occurred in 2013 when bond rates temporarily spiked when markets were caught by surprise by comments from then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke that the Fed was contemplating moves to reduce the size of its monthly purchases of bonds.\n\nThe Fed's balance sheet has soared five-fold - to $4.5 trillion - since the summer of 2008, just before the financial crisis erupted. The increase came as a result of purchases the Fed made of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. The purchases were designed to put downward pressure on long-term interest rates as a way of giving the economy an extra boost after the Fed had cut its short-term rate to a record low near zero.", {"sim": 0.8470588326454163, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9580909", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wtop.com", "title": "WTOP", "id": "6602"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://wtop.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Federal_Reserve_Minutes_18114.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 435, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 445, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2717, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 2728, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://wtop.com/business-finance/2017/08/fed-officials-split-in-july-over-inflation-worries/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:13:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over inflation worries - WTOP", "uri": "710589132", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:32:00Z", "time": "17:32:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Federal Reserve policymakers were worried last month about inflation, but for two opposing reasons.\n\nOne group of Federal Reserve policymakers felt inflation was falling too low and argued for caution in raising interest rates. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory.\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.\"\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December at the earliest. The latest reading of traders' expectations shows less than a 50-50 chance of a December hike, according to the CME Group. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2 percent goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2 percent inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,\" meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.\n\nThe Fed's next meeting is Sept. 19-20.\n\nIn an interview Monday with the Associated Press, William Dudley, head of the Fed's New York regional bank, said that the market's view that the announcement about bond reductions would come in September was \"reasonable.\"\n\nDudley said he did not expect much of an impact on financial markets because the action had been well-telegraphed by the Fed, unlike the \"taper tantrum\" incident that occurred in 2013 when bond rates temporarily spiked when markets were caught by surprise by comments from then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke that the Fed was contemplating moves to reduce the size of its monthly purchases of bonds.\n\nThe Fed's balance sheet has soared five-fold -- to $4.5 trillion -- since the summer of 2008, just before the financial crisis erupted. The increase came as a result of purchases the Fed made of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. The purchases were designed to put downward pressure on long-term interest rates as a way of giving the economy an extra boost after the Fed had cut its short-term rate to a record low near zero.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"sim": 0.8470588326454163, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9570453", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wafb.com", "title": "WAFB", "id": "192"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 434, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 444, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2716, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 2727, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.wafb.com/story/36150328/fed-officials-split-in-july-over-inflation-worries", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:49:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over inflation worries", "uri": "710560316", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:49:00Z", "time": "21:49:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal Reserve policymakers were worried last month about inflation, but for two opposing reasons.\n\nOne group of Federal Reserve policymakers felt inflation was falling too low and argued for caution in raising interest rates. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory.\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.\"\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December at the earliest. The latest reading of traders' expectations shows less than a 50-50 chance of a December hike, according to the CME Group. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2 percent goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2 percent inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,\" meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.\n\nThe Fed's next meeting is Sept. 19-20.\n\nIn an interview Monday with the Associated Press, William Dudley, head of the Fed's New York regional bank, said that the market's view that the announcement about bond reductions would come in September was \"reasonable.\"\n\nDudley said he did not expect much of an impact on financial markets because the action had been well-telegraphed by the Fed, unlike the \"taper tantrum\" incident that occurred in 2013 when bond rates temporarily spiked when markets were caught by surprise by comments from then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke that the Fed was contemplating moves to reduce the size of its monthly purchases of bonds.\n\nThe Fed's balance sheet has soared five-fold - to $4.5 trillion - since the summer of 2008, just before the financial crisis erupted. The increase came as a result of purchases the Fed made of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. The purchases were designed to put downward pressure on long-term interest rates as a way of giving the economy an extra boost after the Fed had cut its short-term rate to a record low near zero.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"sim": 0.8392156958580017, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9551215", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "usatoday.com", "title": "USA Today", "id": "335"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/-mm-/e8849e87e73e1790680c9e7f1d0864d5ae3724d9/c=0-76-3776-2209&r=x803&c=1600x800/local/-/media/2017/08/16/USATODAY/USATODAY/636384933188161936-AFP-AFP-RM4OV-93104363.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 714, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 724, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2961, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 2972, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 233, "textEnd": 240, "date": "2017-08-11", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/markets/2017/08/16/fed-officials-split-july-over-inflation-worries/573644001/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:33:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over inflation worries", "uri": "710507589", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:33:00Z", "time": "19:33:00", "body": "Skip in Skipx\n\nEmbed\n\nx\n\nShare\n\nCLOSE\n\nPresident Donald Trump touted business optimism, the record stock market, and low unemployment as he said the federal government plans to boost apprenticeships and workforce training programs. (Aug. 11) AP\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nWASHINGTON -- Federal Reserve policymakers were worried last month about inflation, but for two opposing reasons.\n\nOne group of Federal Reserve policymakers felt inflation was falling too low and argued for caution in raising interest rates. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory.\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.\"\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December at the earliest. The latest reading of traders' expectations shows less than a 50-50 chance of a December hike, according to the CME Group. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1% to 1.25%. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2% goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3%.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2% inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,\" meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.\n\nThe Fed's next meeting is Sept. 19-20.\n\nIn an interview Monday with the Associated Press, William Dudley, head of the Fed's New York regional bank, said that the market's view that the announcement about bond reductions would come in September was \"reasonable.\"\n\nDudley said he did not expect much of an impact on financial markets because the action had been well-telegraphed by the Fed, unlike the \"taper tantrum\" incident that occurred in 2013 when bond rates temporarily spiked when markets were caught by surprise by comments from then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke that the Fed was contemplating moves to reduce the size of its monthly purchases of bonds.\n\nThe Fed's balance sheet has soared five-fold -- to $4.5 trillion -- since the summer of 2008, just before the financial crisis erupted. The increase came as a result of purchases the Fed made of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. The purchases were designed to put downward pressure on long-term interest rates as a way of giving the economy an extra boost after the Fed had cut its short-term rate to a record low near zero.\n\nRelated:\n\nHere's who the Trump campaign considers 'the president's enemies'\n\nTop Fed official: Bond portfolio could shrink soon\n\nIs inflation finally perking up? Reports this week offer clues\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORERead or Share this story: https://usat.ly/2waYtQ8", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8274509906768799, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9558379", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "todayonline.com", "title": "TODAY", "id": "1197"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.todayonline.com/sites/default/files/photos/43_images/2017-08-16T180437Z_1_LYNXNPED7F1IN_RTROPTP_3_USA-FED.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 288, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 298, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2981, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 2992, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.todayonline.com/business/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation-minutes", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:20:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation: minutes", "uri": "710527044", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:20:00Z", "time": "20:20:00", "body": "WASHINGTON - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for a halt to further interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, at which policymakers voted unanimously to keep rates unchanged, also showed the Fed increasingly ready to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nIn the minutes, released on Wednesday, policymakers had a lengthy discussion about a recent streak of soft inflation readings. Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. Some other Fed officials, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nVoting members of the committee agreed to monitor inflation closely \"in light of their concern about the recent slowing,\" according to the minutes.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year compared to once in each of the previous two years amid low unemployment and continued moderate economic growth. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable. {"sim": 0.8235294222831726, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9544022", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wdsm710.com", "title": "710 WDSM", "id": "2009"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://radiocms-images.us1.eldarioncloud.com/resize/600/https://storage.googleapis.com/media.mwcradio.com/mimesis/2017-08/16/2017-08-16T180754Z_2_LYNXNPED7F1IN-OUSBS_RTROPTP_3_BUSINESS-US-USA-FED-MINUTES.JPG", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 298, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 308, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3003, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3014, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://wdsm710.com/news/articles/2017/aug/16/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation-minutes/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:41:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation: minutes", "uri": "710487935", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:41:00Z", "time": "18:41:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for a halt to further interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, at which policymakers voted unanimously to keep rates unchanged, also showed the Fed increasingly ready to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nIn the minutes, released on Wednesday, policymakers had a lengthy discussion about a recent streak of soft inflation readings. Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. Some other Fed officials, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nVoting members of the committee agreed to monitor inflation closely \"in light of their concern about the recent slowing,\" according to the minutes.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year compared to once in each of the previous two years amid low unemployment and continued moderate economic growth. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nThe dollar\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.\n\n(Reporting by Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange; Editing Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. Some other Fed officials, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nVoting members of the committee agreed to monitor inflation closely \"in light of their concern about the recent slowing,\" according to the minutes.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year compared to once in each of the previous two years amid low unemployment and continued moderate economic growth. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nThe dollar .DXY weakened against a basket of currencies after the release of the minutes. U.S. stocks pared gains while prices of U.S. Treasuries were largely unchanged.\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and {"sim": 0.8235294222831726, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9633225", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "title": "RTE.ie", "id": "1151"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://img.rasset.ie/0007f796-1600.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 268, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 278, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2771, "textEnd": 2785, "date": "-12-12", "dateEnd": "-12-13", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3508, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3523, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2017/0817/897993-us-central-bank/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:34:00", "title": "US central bankers wary over weak inflation", "uri": "710743006", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T07:34:00Z", "time": "07:34:00", "body": "US Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for halting interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the 25-26 July meeting, released yesterday, also indicated the Fed was poised to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nLast month's meeting, which concluded with a unanimous decision to leave rates unchanged, was marked by a lengthy discussion about the recent soft inflation readings, the minutes showed.\n\nThe central bank's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5% in June from 1.8% in February and has remained below its 2% target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2% for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nThe inflation retreat has spurred concerns the Fed may have to cool its monetary tightening pace even though the economy is growing moderately and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3% in July, matching a 16-year low touched in May.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year and forecasts one more rise before the end of 2017.\n\nSome policymakers argued last month against future rate rises until there was more concrete evidence that inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective, according to the minutes.\n\nOthers, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation given a tightening labour market \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nIn an interview with Reuters, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said, \"I'm not one who would like to see inflation be at 2% before we continue on the path\" of rate hikes because policy affects the economy with a lag.\n\n\"On the other hand, we do have to take into account that we have had weak readings on inflation,\" Ms Mester added.\n\nSenior Fed officials have largely dismissed the inflation softness as temporary. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last month that special factors, including price drops for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible.\n\nVoting members of the Fed' rate-setting committee agreed to monitor inflation closely in light of the concerns, with a few policymakers cautioning that the central bank's framework for analysing inflation was \"not particularly useful,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"What it boils down to is what inflation will do between here and December,\" said Eric Winograd, an economist at Alliance Bernstein, who still expects the Fed to raise rates again at its 12-13 December meeting.\n\nFed policymakers at last month's meeting also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials reinforced expectations of an announcement in September to begin reducing the central bank's holdings of bonds that were bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nSeveral policymakers were prepared to announce a start date last month, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on 19-20 September. New York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "630"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://s4.reutersmedia.net/resources/r/?m=02&d=20170817&t=2&i=1197441228&w=&fh=545px&fw=&ll=&pl=&sq=&r=LYNXNPED7F1IS", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 293, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 303, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2852, "textEnd": 2862, "date": "-12-12", "dateEnd": "-12-13", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3751, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3762, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "https://in.reuters.com/article/usa-fed-minutes-idINKCN1AW2B5", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:41:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation", "uri": "710678261", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:41:00Z", "time": "04:41:00", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for halting interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the U.S. central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, released on Wednesday, also indicated the Fed was poised to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nLast month's meeting, which concluded with a unanimous decision to leave rates unchanged, was marked by a lengthy discussion about the recent soft inflation readings, the minutes showed.\n\nThe central bank's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February and has remained below its 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nThe inflation retreat has spurred concerns the Fed may have to cool its monetary tightening pace even though the economy is growing moderately and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, matching a 16-year low touched in May.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year and forecasts one more rise before the end of 2017.\n\nSome policymakers argued last month against future rate rises until there was more concrete evidence that inflation was moving back towards the Fed's objective, according to the minutes.\n\nOthers, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation given a tightening labour market \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nIn an interview with Reuters on Wednesday, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said, \"I'm not one who would like to see inflation be at 2 percent before we continue on the path\" of rate hikes because policy affects the economy with a lag.\n\n\"On the other hand, we do have to take into account that we have had weak readings on inflation,\" Mester added.\n\nSenior Fed officials have largely dismissed the inflation softness as temporary. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last month that special factors, including price drops for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible.\n\nVoting members of the Fed' rate-setting committee agreed to monitor inflation closely in light of the concerns, with a few policymakers cautioning that the central bank's framework for analysing inflation was \"not particularly useful,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"What it boils down to is what inflation will do between here and December,\" said Eric Winograd, an economist at Alliance Bernstein, who still expects the Fed to raise rates again at its Dec. 12-13 meeting.\n\nThe dollar .DXY was weaker against a basket of currencies. U.S. stocks ended slightly stronger after paring earlier gains and prices of U.S. Treasuries were higher.\n\nFed policymakers at last month's meeting also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials reinforced expectations of an announcement in September to begin reducing the central bank's holdings of bonds that were bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nSeveral policymakers were prepared to announce a start date last month, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20. New York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8156862854957581, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9542660", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailysabah.com", "title": "DailySabah", "id": "1235"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://iadsb.tmgrup.com.tr/500238/645/344/0/78/1640/953?u=https://idsb.tmgrup.com.tr/2017/08/16/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation-minutes-1502907534924.jpeg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 275, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 285, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3165, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3176, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.dailysabah.com/finance/2017/08/16/fed-officials-split-in-july-over-path-of-rate-hikes-inflation-worries-minutes", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:33:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over path of rate hikes, inflation worries: minutes", "uri": "710484298", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:33:00Z", "time": "18:33:00", "body": "Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for a halt to further interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, at which policymakers voted unanimously to keep rates unchanged, also showed the Fed increasingly ready to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nIn the minutes, released on Wednesday, policymakers had a lengthy discussion about a recent streak of soft inflation readings. Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. Some other Fed officials, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nVoting members of the committee agreed to monitor inflation closely \"in light of their concern about the recent slowing,\" according to the minutes.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year compared to once in each of the previous two years amid low unemployment and continued moderate economic growth. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nThe dollar weakened against a basket of currencies after the release of the minutes. U.S. stocks pared gains while prices of U.S. Treasuries were largely unchanged.\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION NEARS\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8156862854957581, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9540573", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 275, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 285, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2999, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3010, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/business/report-fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation-minutes-2532284", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:18:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation -minutes", "uri": "710479008", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:18:00Z", "time": "18:18:00", "body": "Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for a halt to further interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, at which policymakers voted unanimously to keep rates unchanged, also showed the Fed increasingly ready to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nIn the minutes, released on Wednesday, policymakers had a lengthy discussion about a recent streak of soft inflation readings. Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. Some other Fed officials, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nVoting members of the committee agreed to monitor inflation closely \"in light of their concern about the recent slowing,\" according to the minutes.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year compared to once in each of the previous two years amid low unemployment and continued moderate economic growth. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION NEARS\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team {"sim": 0.8117647171020508, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9669103", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "title": "Yahoo Finance", "id": "5636"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 330, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 340, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2935, "textEnd": 2945, "date": "-12-12", "dateEnd": "-12-13", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3836, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3851, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-180450852.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:58:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation", "uri": "710834217", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T03:23:00Z", "time": "03:23:00", "body": "By Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for halting interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the U.S. central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, released on Wednesday, also indicated the Fed was poised to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion (3.27 trillion pounds)portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nLast month's meeting, which concluded with a unanimous decision to leave rates unchanged, was marked by a lengthy discussion about the recent soft inflation readings, the minutes showed.\n\nThe central bank's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February and has remained below its 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nThe inflation retreat has spurred concerns the Fed may have to cool its monetary tightening pace even though the economy is growing moderately and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, matching a 16-year low touched in May.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year and forecasts one more rise before the end of 2017.\n\nSome policymakers argued last month against future rate rises until there was more concrete evidence that inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective, according to the minutes.\n\nOthers, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation given a tightening labour market \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION\n\nIn an interview with Reuters on Wednesday, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said, \"I'm not one who would like to see inflation be at 2 percent before we continue on the path\" of rate hikes because policy affects the economy with a lag.\n\n\"On the other hand, we do have to take into account that we have had weak readings on inflation,\" Mester added.\n\nSenior Fed officials have largely dismissed the inflation softness as temporary. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last month that special factors, including price drops for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible.\n\nVoting members of the Fed' rate-setting committee agreed to monitor inflation closely in light of the concerns, with a few policymakers cautioning that the central bank's framework for analysing inflation was \"not particularly useful,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"What it boils down to is what inflation will do between here and December,\" said Eric Winograd, an economist at Alliance Bernstein, who still expects the Fed to raise rates again at its Dec. 12-13 meeting.\n\nThe dollar (.DXY) was weaker against a basket of currencies. U.S. stocks ended slightly stronger after paring earlier gains and prices of U.S. Treasuries were higher.\n\nFed policymakers at last month's meeting also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials reinforced expectations of an announcement in September to begin reducing the central bank's holdings of bonds that were bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nSeveral policymakers were prepared to announce a start date last month, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on September 19-20. New York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.\n\n(Reporting by Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange; Additional reporting by Jonathan Spicer and Howard Schneider in New York; Editing by Paul Simao)", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": {"sim": 0.8117647171020508, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9546394", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "title": "Channel NewsAsia", "id": "1555"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.channelnewsasia.com/image/9129674/16x9/991/529/6c797c99152848476609dbfa8311da53/pn/the-seal-for-the-board-of-governors-of-the-federal-reserve-system-is-displayed-in-washington-1.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 287, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 297, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3179, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3190, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation--minutes-9129676", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:59:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation: minutes", "uri": "710494580", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:59:00Z", "time": "18:59:00", "body": "WASHINGTON: Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for a halt to further interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, at which policymakers voted unanimously to keep rates unchanged, also showed the Fed increasingly ready to begin reducing its US$4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nIn the minutes, released on Wednesday, policymakers had a lengthy discussion about a recent streak of soft inflation readings. Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. Some other Fed officials, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nVoting members of the committee agreed to monitor inflation closely \"in light of their concern about the recent slowing,\" according to the minutes.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year compared to once in each of the previous two years amid low unemployment and continued moderate economic growth. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nThe dollar weakened against a basket of currencies after the release of the minutes. U.S. stocks pared gains while prices of U.S. Treasuries were largely unchanged.\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION NEARS\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.\n\n(Reporting by Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange; Editing Business Line", "id": "1133"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/multimedia/dynamic/03193/fed_3193705g.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 268, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 278, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2900, "textEnd": 2914, "date": "-12-12", "dateEnd": "-12-13", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3813, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3828, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/world/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation/article9820682.ece", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:25:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation", "uri": "710673969", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:25:00Z", "time": "04:25:00", "body": "Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for halting interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the US central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, released on Wednesday, also indicated the Fed was poised to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nLast month's meeting, which concluded with a unanimous decision to leave rates unchanged, was marked by a lengthy discussion about the recent soft inflation readings, the minutes showed.\n\nInflation measure\n\nThe central bank's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 per cent in June from 1.8 per cent in February and has remained below its 2 per cent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nMonetary tightening pace\n\nThe inflation retreat has spurred concerns the Fed may have to cool its monetary tightening pace even though the economy is growing moderately and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 per cent in July, matching a 16-year low touched in May.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year and forecasts one more rise before the end of 2017.\n\nSome policymakers argued last month against future rate rises until there was more concrete evidence that inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective, according to the minutes.\n\nOthers, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation given a tightening labor market \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nBalance sheet reduction\n\nIn an interview with Reuters on Wednesday, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said, \"I'm not one who would like to see inflation be at 2 per cent before we continue on the path\" of rate hikes because policy affects the economy with a lag.\n\n\"On the other hand, we do have to take into account that we have had weak readings on inflation,\" Mester added.\n\nSenior Fed officials have largely dismissed the inflation softness as temporary. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last month that special factors, including price drops for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible.\n\nVoting members of the Fed' rate-setting committee agreed to monitor inflation closely in light of the concerns, with a few policymakers cautioning that the central bank's framework for analyzing inflation was \"not particularly useful,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"What it boils down to is what inflation will do between here and December,\" said Eric Winograd, an economist at Alliance Bernstein, who still expects the Fed to raise rates again at its December 12-13 meeting.\n\nUS Treasuries\n\nThe dollar was weaker against a basket of currencies. US stocks ended slightly stronger after paring earlier gains and the prices of US Treasuries were higher.\n\nFed policymakers at last month's meeting also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials reinforced expectations of an announcement in September to begin reducing the central bank's holdings of bonds that were bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nSeveral policymakers were prepared to announce a start date last month, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on September 19-20. New York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8039215803146362, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9609392", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 330, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 340, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2914, "textEnd": 2924, "date": "-12-12", "dateEnd": "-12-13", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3808, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3819, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation/articleshow/60096804.cms", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:23:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation - Times of India", "uri": "710673279", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T04:23:00Z", "time": "04:23:00", "body": "By Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for halting interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the U.S. central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, released on Wednesday, also indicated the Fed was poised to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nLast month's meeting, which concluded with a unanimous decision to leave rates unchanged, was marked by a lengthy discussion about the recent soft inflation readings, the minutes showed.\n\nThe central bank's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February and has remained below its 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nThe inflation retreat has spurred concerns the Fed may have to cool its monetary tightening pace even though the economy is growing moderately and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, matching a 16-year low touched in May.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year and forecasts one more rise before the end of 2017.\n\nSome policymakers argued last month against future rate rises until there was more concrete evidence that inflation was moving back towards the Fed's objective, according to the minutes.\n\nOthers, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation given a tightening labour market \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION\n\nIn an interview with Reuters on Wednesday, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said, \"I'm not one who would like to see inflation be at 2 percent before we continue on the path\" of rate hikes because policy affects the economy with a lag.\n\n\"On the other hand, we do have to take into account that we have had weak readings on inflation,\" Mester added.\n\nSenior Fed officials have largely dismissed the inflation softness as temporary. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last month that special factors, including price drops for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible.\n\nVoting members of the Fed' rate-setting committee agreed to monitor inflation closely in light of the concerns, with a few policymakers cautioning that the central bank's framework for analysing inflation was \"not particularly useful,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"What it boils down to is what inflation will do between here and December,\" said Eric Winograd, an economist at Alliance Bernstein, who still expects the Fed to raise rates again at its Dec. 12-13 meeting.\n\nThe dollar was weaker against a basket of currencies. U.S. stocks ended slightly stronger after paring earlier gains and prices of U.S. Treasuries were higher.\n\nFed policymakers at last month's meeting also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials reinforced expectations of an announcement in September to begin reducing the central bank's holdings of bonds that were bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nSeveral policymakers were prepared to announce a start date last month, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20. New York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.\n\n(Reporting by Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange; Additional reporting by Jonathan Spicer and Howard Schneider in New York; Editing by Paul Simao)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.",
