"http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation/articleshow/60094482.cms", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:54:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation - Times of India", "uri": "710539109", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:54:00Z", "time": "20:54:00", "body": "(Adds quotes from economist, Fed's Mester; updates markets)\n\nBy Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange\n\nWASHINGTON, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for halting interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the U.S. central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, released on Wednesday, also indicated the Fed was poised to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nLast month's meeting, which concluded with a unanimous decision to leave rates unchanged, was marked by a lengthy discussion about the recent soft inflation readings, the minutes showed.\n\nThe central bank's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February and has remained below its 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nThe inflation retreat has spurred concerns the Fed may have to cool its monetary tightening pace even though the economy is growing moderately and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, matching a 16-year low touched in May.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year and forecasts one more rise before the end of 2017.\n\nSome policymakers argued last month against future rate rises until there was more concrete evidence that inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective, according to the minutes.\n\nOthers, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation given a tightening labor market \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION\n\nIn an interview with Reuters on Wednesday, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said, \"I'm not one who would like to see inflation be at 2 percent before we continue on the path\" of rate hikes because policy affects the economy with a lag.\n\n\"On the other hand, we do have to take into account that we have had weak readings on inflation,\" Mester added.\n\nSenior Fed officials have largely dismissed the inflation softness as temporary. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last month that special factors, including price drops for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible.\n\nVoting members of the Fed' rate-setting committee agreed to monitor inflation closely in light of the concerns, with a few policymakers cautioning that the central bank's framework for analyzing inflation was \"not particularly useful,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"What it boils down to is what inflation will do between here and December,\" said Eric Winograd, an economist at Alliance Bernstein, who still expects the Fed to raise rates again at its Dec. 12-13 meeting.\n\nThe dollar was weaker against a basket of currencies. U.S. stocks ended slightly stronger after paring earlier gains and prices of U.S. Treasuries were higher.\n\nFed policymakers at last month's meeting also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials reinforced expectations of an announcement in September to begin reducing the central bank's holdings of bonds that were bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nSeveral policymakers were prepared to announce a start date last month, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20. New York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.\n\n(Reporting by Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange; Additional reporting by Jonathan Spicer and Howard Schneider in New York; Editing by Paul Simao)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", {"sim": 0.8039215803146362, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9562784", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 338, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 348, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2920, "textEnd": 2930, "date": "-12-12", "dateEnd": "-12-13", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3814, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3825, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 49, "textEnd": 55, "date": "2017-08-16", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4797248/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:53:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation", "uri": "710538400", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T20:53:00Z", "time": "20:53:00", "body": "By Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange\n\nWASHINGTON, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for halting interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the U.S. central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, released on Wednesday, also indicated the Fed was poised to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nLast month's meeting, which concluded with a unanimous decision to leave rates unchanged, was marked by a lengthy discussion about the recent soft inflation readings, the minutes showed.\n\nThe central bank's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February and has remained below its 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nThe inflation retreat has spurred concerns the Fed may have to cool its monetary tightening pace even though the economy is growing moderately and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, matching a 16-year low touched in May.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year and forecasts one more rise before the end of 2017.\n\nSome policymakers argued last month against future rate rises until there was more concrete evidence that inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective, according to the minutes.\n\nOthers, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation given a tightening labor market \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION\n\nIn an interview with Reuters on Wednesday, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said, \"I'm not one who would like to see inflation be at 2 percent before we continue on the path\" of rate hikes because policy affects the economy with a lag.\n\n\"On the other hand, we do have to take into account that we have had weak readings on inflation,\" Mester added.\n\nSenior Fed officials have largely dismissed the inflation softness as temporary. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last month that special factors, including price drops for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible.\n\nVoting members of the Fed' rate-setting committee agreed to monitor inflation closely in light of the concerns, with a few policymakers cautioning that the central bank's framework for analyzing inflation was \"not particularly useful,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"What it boils down to is what inflation will do between here and December,\" said Eric Winograd, an economist at Alliance Bernstein, who still expects the Fed to raise rates again at its Dec. 12-13 meeting.\n\nThe dollar was weaker against a basket of currencies. U.S. stocks ended slightly stronger after paring earlier gains and prices of U.S. Treasuries were higher.\n\nFed policymakers at last month's meeting also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials reinforced expectations of an announcement in September to begin reducing the central bank's holdings of bonds that were bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nSeveral policymakers were prepared to announce a start date last month, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20. New York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable.\n\n(Reporting by Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange; Additional reporting by Jonathan Spicer and Howard Schneider in New York; Editing by Paul Simao)", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION NEARS\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable. Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION NEARS\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. {"sim": 0.7960784435272217, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9546222", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 367, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 377, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3257, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3268, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 73, "textEnd": 79, "date": "2017-08-16", "amb": false}], "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/fed-policymakers-grow-more-worried-about-weak-inflation-minutes/articleshow/60092858.cms", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:57:00", "title": "Fed policymakers grow more worried about weak inflation -minutes - Times of India", "uri": "710493876", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:57:00Z", "time": "18:57:00", "body": "(Adds market reaction)\n\nBy Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange\n\nWASHINGTON, Aug 16 (Reuters) - Federal Reserve policymakers appeared increasingly wary about recent weak inflation and some called for a halt to further interest rate hikes until it was clear the trend was transitory, according to the minutes of the central bank's last policy meeting.\n\nThe readout of the July 25-26 meeting, at which policymakers voted unanimously to keep rates unchanged, also showed the Fed increasingly ready to begin reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities.\n\nIn the minutes, released on Wednesday, policymakers had a lengthy discussion about a recent streak of soft inflation readings. Inflation has remained below the central bank's 2 percent target for more than five years.\n\n\"Many participants ... saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below 2 percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that the risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the Fed said in the minutes.\n\nSome participants on the policy-setting committee argued against further rate rises until data had confirmed inflation was moving back toward the Fed's objective. Some other Fed officials, however, cautioned that such a delay could cause an eventual overshooting in inflation \"that would likely be costly to reverse.\"\n\nVoting members of the committee agreed to monitor inflation closely \"in light of their concern about the recent slowing,\" according to the minutes.\n\nThe Fed has raised its benchmark overnight lending rate twice this year compared to once in each of the previous two years amid low unemployment and continued moderate economic growth. It currently forecasts one more rate rise before the end of this year.\n\nBut a retreat in inflation in the past few months has caused some disquiet that the Fed may have to cool its current pace of monetary tightening, despite senior central bank officials largely dismissing the softness as transitory.\n\nFed Chair Janet Yellen told lawmakers last month that \"some special factors,\" including a drop in prices for mobile phone plans and prescription drugs, were partly responsible for the weak inflation data.\n\nIn the minutes, however, a few Fed policymakers cautioned that the framework the central bank uses to analyze inflation \"was not particularly useful.\"\n\nThe Fed's preferred inflation measure dropped to 1.5 percent in June from 1.8 percent in February.\n\nThe dollar weakened against a basket of currencies after the release of the minutes. U.S. stocks pared gains while prices of U.S. Treasuries were largely unchanged.\n\nBALANCE SHEET REDUCTION NEARS\n\nPolicymakers also cast a keener light on financial stability and agreed it was important to look for signs of declining market volatility or concentration of investors in particular assets.\n\nElsewhere in the minutes, Fed officials showed they are closer to beginning to reduce the central bank's bond portfolio. Several policymakers were prepared to announce a start date at the June meeting, but the Fed decided to wait as \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting.\"\n\nFed officials have been priming markets for a probable move at their next policy meeting on Sept. 19-20 to begin reducing the bond holdings, bought in the wake of the 2007-2009 financial crisis and recession.\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley said on Monday the expectation of such an announcement next month was not unreasonable. (Reporting by Lindsay Dunsmuir and Jason Lange; Editing by Paul Simao)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", {"sim": 0.7921568751335144, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9669116", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "thestandard.com.hk", "title": "The Standard", "id": "10724"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 451, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 461, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news.php?id=95314&sid=2", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:58:00", "title": "Fed officials split in July over inflation worries", "uri": "710834239", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T02:23:00Z", "time": "02:23:00", "body": "Federal Reserve policymakers were worried last month about inflation, but for two opposing reasons.\n\nOne group of Federal Reserve policymakers felt inflation was falling too low and argued for caution in raising interest rates. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory. (Pictured, Fed chair Janet Yellen)\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.''\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2 percent goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2 percent inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,'' meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.", "date": {"sim": 0.7882353067398071, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9258169", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "wafb.com", "title": "WAFB", "id": "192"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://images.worldnow.com/AP/images/14650222_G.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 4732, "textEnd": 4740, "date": "2017-09-20", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.wafb.com/story/36131231/top-fed-official-tells-ap-bond-portfolio-could-shrink-soon", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:49:00", "title": "Top Fed official tells AP: Bond portfolio could shrink soon", "uri": "709713228", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T10:49:00Z", "time": "10:49:00", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - A top Federal Reserve official suggested Monday that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio - a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nIn an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin trimming its bond holdings.\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans. He noted that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate - a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline. In its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nOn other topics, Dudley:\n\n- Suggested that Gary Cohn, who leads President Donald Trump's National Economic Council and is close to Trump, would be a \"reasonable candidate\" to succeed Yellen as Fed chair if Trump chooses not to re-nominate Yellen when her term ends early next year. Dudley, who worked with Cohn as top officials at Goldman Sachs, said Cohn \"knows a lot about financial markets,\" and \"I don't think you have to have a Ph.D. in economics\" to lead the Fed. In a recent interview, Trump said he was considering both Yellen and Cohn for the top Fed job, along with some other candidates he would not name.\n\n- Expressed confidence that the Fed's political independence, long considered essential for it to carry out its functions, would remain respected during a Trump presidency. Trump may have the opportunity to install up to five members of the Fed's seven-member board over the next year, and the president has shown a tendency to expect loyalty from some people he has named to key positions. Trump had offered a harsh judgment of the Fed and of Yellen during the presidential campaign but has since avoided making critical comments. Dudley noted that the Trump administration has so far been \"very hands-off\" toward the Fed, \"very respectful of the monetary policy.\"\n\n- Said that even as stock prices set record highs and other assets surge as well, he isn't concerned that any potentially devastating asset bubbles might be forming, akin to the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 crisis. Dudley said asset prices \"are pretty consistent with what we are seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy,\" which he said has been evolving without much volatility.\n\n-Acknowledged that policymakers need to be \"somewhat humble\" about how the forthcoming reduction in the Fed's bond portfolio might affect financial markets and loan rates. Dudley noted that the Fed has never before had to pare a balance sheet that has grown five-fold to $4.5 trillion. But he said officials have learned from the 2013 \"taper tantrum\" that rocked markets after a surprise announcement from the Fed, and has sought to telegraph all its actions well in advance.\n\nThe Fed's announcement that it will start paring its bond portfolio is expected to come after its next policy meeting ends Sept. 20. The meeting after that, in December, is when many Fed watchers expect the next increase in its key short-term rate, which remains in a still-low range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent.\n\nYellen and other Fed officials have attributed the persistently low inflation rate, which slowed further in recent months, to such transitory events as a sharp drop in cellphone fees.\n\nDudley said that if the economy evolves during the rest of 2017 as he expects, with inflation rebounding, \"I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"sim": 0.7882353067398071, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9153186", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailyrepublic.com", "title": "Daily Republic", "id": "4795"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 4736, "textEnd": 4744, "date": "2017-09-20", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailyrepublic.com/business/top-fed-official-tells-ap-bond-portfolio-could-shrink-soon/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:02:00", "title": "Top Fed official tells AP: Bond portfolio could shrink soon", "uri": "709419579", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:27:00Z", "time": "19:27:00", "body": "NEW YORK -- A top Federal Reserve official suggested Monday that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio -- a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nIn an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin selling some of those bonds.\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans. He noted that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate -- a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline. In its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nOn other topics, Dudley:\n\n-- Suggested that Gary Cohn, who leads President Donald Trump's National Economic Council and is close to Trump, would be a \"reasonable candidate\" to succeed Yellen as Fed chair if Trump chooses not to re-nominate Yellen when her term ends early next year. Dudley, who worked with Cohn as top officials at Goldman Sachs, said Cohn \"knows a lot about financial markets,\" and \"I don't think you have to have a Ph.D. in economics\" to lead the Fed. In a recent interview, Trump said he was considering both Yellen and Cohn for the top Fed job, along with some other candidates he would not name.\n\n-- Expressed confidence that the Fed's political independence, long considered essential for it to carry out its functions, would remain respected during a Trump presidency. Trump may have the opportunity to install up to five members of the Fed's seven-member board over the next year, and the president has shown a tendency to expect loyalty from some people he has named to key positions. Trump had offered a harsh judgment of the Fed and of Yellen during the presidential campaign but has since avoided making critical comments. Dudley noted that the Trump administration has so far been \"very hands-off\" toward the Fed, \"very respectful of the monetary policy.\"\n\n-- Said that even as stock prices set record highs and other assets surge as well, he isn't concerned that any potentially devastating asset bubbles might be forming, akin to the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 crisis. Dudley said asset prices \"are pretty consistent with what we are seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy,\" which he said has been evolving without much volatility.\n\n-- Acknowledged that policymakers need to be \"somewhat humble\" about how the forthcoming reduction in the Fed's bond portfolio might affect financial markets and loan rates. Dudley noted that the Fed has never before had to pare a balance sheet that has grown five-fold to $4.5 trillion. But he said officials have learned from the 2013 \"taper tantrum\" that rocked markets after a surprise announcement from the Fed, and has sought to telegraph all its actions well in advance.\n\nThe Fed's announcement that it will start paring its bond portfolio is expected to come after its next policy meeting ends Sept. 20. The meeting after that, in December, is when many Fed watchers expect the next increase in its key short-term rate, which remains in a still-low range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent.\n\nYellen and other Fed officials have attributed the persistently low inflation rate, which slowed further in recent months, to such transitory events as a sharp drop in cellphone fees.\n\nDudley said that if the economy evolves during the rest of 2017 as he expects, with inflation rebounding, \"I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7803921699523926, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9207214", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "fox13memphis.com", "title": "WHBQ", "id": "114"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://cmgfeeds.cmgdigital.com/photo/2017/08/14/Federal_Reserve-Dudley_Interview_10079_8856672_ver1.0_1280_720.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 4497, "textEnd": 4505, "date": "2017-09-20", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.fox13memphis.com/news/top-fed-official-tells-ap-bond-portfolio-could-shrink-soon/591437202", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:31:00", "title": "Top Fed official tells AP: Bond portfolio could shrink soon", "uri": "709571486", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T04:31:00Z", "time": "04:31:00", "body": "In an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin trimming its bond holdings.\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans. He noted that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate - a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline. In its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nOn other topics, Dudley:\n\n- Suggested that Gary Cohn, who leads President Donald Trump's National Economic Council and is close to Trump, would be a \"reasonable candidate\" to succeed Yellen as Fed chair if Trump chooses not to re-nominate Yellen when her term ends early next year. Dudley, who worked with Cohn as top officials at Goldman Sachs, said Cohn \"knows a lot about financial markets,\" and \"I don't think you have to have a Ph.D. in economics\" to lead the Fed. In a recent interview, Trump said he was considering both Yellen and Cohn for the top Fed job, along with some other candidates he would not name.\n\n- Expressed confidence that the Fed's political independence, long considered essential for it to carry out its functions, would remain respected during a Trump presidency. Trump may have the opportunity to install up to five members of the Fed's seven-member board over the next year, and the president has shown a tendency to expect loyalty from some people he has named to key positions. Trump had offered a harsh judgment of the Fed and of Yellen during the presidential campaign but has since avoided making critical comments. Dudley noted that the Trump administration has so far been \"very hands-off\" toward the Fed, \"very respectful of the monetary policy.\"\n\n- Said that even as stock prices set record highs and other assets surge as well, he isn't concerned that any potentially devastating asset bubbles might be forming, akin to the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 crisis. Dudley said asset prices \"are pretty consistent with what we are seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy,\" which he said has been evolving without much volatility.\n\n-Acknowledged that policymakers need to be \"somewhat humble\" about how the forthcoming reduction in the Fed's bond portfolio might affect financial markets and loan rates. Dudley noted that the Fed has never before had to pare a balance sheet that has grown five-fold to $4.5 trillion. But he said officials have learned from the 2013 \"taper tantrum\" that rocked markets after a surprise announcement from the Fed, and has sought to telegraph all its actions well in advance.\n\nThe Fed's announcement that it will start paring its bond portfolio is expected to come after its next policy meeting ends Sept. 20. The meeting after that, in December, is when many Fed watchers expect the next increase in its key short-term rate, which remains in a still-low range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent.\n\nYellen and other Fed officials have attributed the persistently low inflation rate, which slowed further in recent months, to such transitory events as a sharp drop in cellphone fees.\n\nDudley said that if the economy evolves during the rest of 2017 as he expects, with inflation rebounding, \"I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin selling some of those bonds.\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nFILE - In this Tuesday, March 21, 2017, file photo, William C. Dudley, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, speaks during a panel discussion at The Bank of England in London. In an interview with The Associated Press, Dudley indicated that the Fed will likely make an announcement at its September 2017 meeting that it is ready to start reducing its massive bond portfolio, a move expected to put upward pressure on long-term interest rates including home mortgages. (AP Photo/Kirsty Wigglesworth, Pool, File)\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans. He noted that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate - a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline. In its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nOn other topics, Dudley:\n\n- Suggested that Gary Cohn, who leads President Donald Trump's National Economic Council and is close to Trump, would be a \"reasonable candidate\" to succeed Yellen as Fed chair if Trump chooses not to re-nominate Yellen when her term ends early next year. Dudley, who worked with Cohn as top officials at Goldman Sachs, said Cohn \"knows a lot about financial markets,\" and \"I don't think you have to have a Ph.D. in economics\" to lead the Fed. In a recent interview, Trump said he was considering both Yellen and Cohn for the top Fed job, along with some other candidates he would not name.\n\n- Expressed confidence that the Fed's political independence, long considered essential for it to carry out its functions, would remain respected during a Trump presidency. Trump may have the opportunity to install up to five members of the Fed's seven-member board over the next year, and the president has shown a tendency to expect loyalty from some people he has named to key positions. Trump had offered a harsh judgment of the Fed and of Yellen during the presidential campaign but has since avoided making critical comments. Dudley noted that the Trump administration has so far been \"very hands-off\" toward the Fed, \"very respectful of monetary policy.\"\n\n- Said that even as stock prices set record highs and other assets surge as well, he isn't concerned that any potentially devastating asset bubbles might be forming, akin to the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 crisis. Dudley said asset prices \"are pretty consistent with what we are seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy,\" which he said has been evolving without much volatility.\n\nThe Fed's announcement that it will start paring its bond portfolio is expected to come after its next policy meeting ends Sept. 20. The meeting after that, in December, is when many Fed watchers expect the next increase in its key short-term rate, which remains in a still-low range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent.\n\nYellen and other Fed officials have attributed the persistently low inflation rate, which slowed further in recent months, to such transitory events as a sharp drop in cellphone fees.\n\nDudley said that if the {"sim": 0.7803921699523926, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9141476", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "sfgate.com", "title": "San Francisco Gate", "id": "530"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://ww2.hdnux.com/photos/64/34/50/13748781/3/rawImage.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 4258, "textEnd": 4266, "date": "2017-09-20", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Top-Fed-official-tells-AP-Bond-portfolio-could-11817892.php", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:41:00", "title": "Top Fed official tells AP: Bond portfolio could shrink soon", "uri": "709387291", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:41:00Z", "time": "18:41:00", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- A top Federal Reserve official suggested Monday that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio -- a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nIn an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin selling some of those bonds.\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans. He noted that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate -- a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline. In its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nOn other topics, Dudley:\n\n-- Suggested that Gary Cohn, who leads President Donald Trump's National Economic Council and is close to Trump, would be a \"reasonable candidate\" to succeed Yellen as Fed chair if Trump chooses not to re-nominate Yellen when her term ends early next year. Dudley, who worked with Cohn as top officials at Goldman Sachs, said Cohn \"knows a lot about financial markets,\" and \"I don't think you have to have a Ph.D. in economics\" to lead the Fed. In a recent interview, Trump said he was considering both Yellen and Cohn for the top Fed job, along with some other candidates he would not name.\n\n-- Expressed confidence that the Fed's political independence, long considered essential for it to carry out its functions, would remain respected during a Trump presidency. Trump may have the opportunity to install up to five members of the Fed's seven-member board over the next year, and the president has shown a tendency to expect loyalty from some people he has named to key positions. Trump had offered a harsh judgment of the Fed and of Yellen during the presidential campaign but has since avoided making critical comments. Dudley noted that the Trump administration has so far been \"very hands-off\" toward the Fed, \"very respectful of monetary policy.\"\n\n-- Said that even as stock prices set record highs and other assets surge as well, he isn't concerned that any potentially devastating asset bubbles might be forming, akin to the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 crisis. Dudley said asset prices \"are pretty consistent with what we are seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy,\" which he said has been evolving without much volatility.\n\nThe Fed's announcement that it will start paring its bond portfolio is expected to come after its next policy meeting ends Sept. 20. The meeting after that, in December, is when many Fed watchers expect the next increase in its key short-term rate, which remains in a still-low range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent.\n\nYellen and other Fed officials have attributed the persistently low inflation rate, which slowed further in recent months, to such transitory events as a sharp drop in cellphone fees.\n\nDudley said that if the economy evolves during the rest of 2017 as he expects, with inflation rebounding, \"I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri": "971"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.trbimg.com/img-599489ef/turbine/la-fi-federal-reserve-minutes-20170816", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 360, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 370, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1810, "textEnd": 1817, "date": "2017-06-30", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-federal-reserve-minutes-20170816-story.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:13:00", "title": "Several Fed officials wanted to set a date for asset reductions but policymakers left the timeline vague", "uri": "710476518", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:13:00Z", "time": "18:13:00", "body": "Several Federal Reserve monetary policymakers wanted to announce last month exactly when they would start reducing the central bank's trillions of dollars in assets, but most preferred to wait to see how the economy and financial markets were doing over the summer, according to an account of the meeting released Wednesday.\n\nIn the formal statement after the July 25-26 meeting, the Federal Open Market Committee said the scale back of the Fed's $4.5 trillion balance sheet would happen \"relatively soon.\"\n\nAnalysts have expected Fed officials to start the reductions when they next meet in September.\n\nBut the minutes of the July meeting, released with the usual three-week lag, indicated Fed policymakers \"expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation.\" That development could lead them to hold off on the balance sheet reduction as well as future hikes in a key interest rate.\n\nFed officials are trying to return to a more normal monetary policy after years of rock-bottom interest rates and a dramatic expansion of Fed assets that were designed to stimulate the economy during and after the Great Recession.\n\nMost Fed policymakers saw the outlook for the economy and the labor market \"little changed\" in July from their earlier projections, which included inflation rising to the central bank's 2% annual target over the next couple of years, the minutes showed.\n\nThat would put Fed officials on target for another small increase in their benchmark short-term interest rate before the end of the year.\n\nIn June, Fed policymakers voted 8-1 to increase the rate by 0.25 percentage point, the third such increase in six months. The rate now is between 1% and 1.25%.\n\nBut Fed officials continue to be worried that inflation remains too low, according to the meeting minutes. For the 12-months ended June 30, the most recent data available, the Fed's preferred inflation measure was 1.4%.\n\nFed Chairwoman Janet L. Yellen has attributed the recent slowdown in inflation mostly to temporary factors, such as lower costs for cellphone plans.\n\nMany Fed policymakers at the July meeting agreed, but said inflation \"would likely continue to be held down over the second half of the year by the effects of those factors,\" the minutes said.\n\nGiven the low inflation, some officials said the Fed \"could afford to be patient\" on future interest rate hikes. But some others were worried that without additional hikes, inflation might accelerate above the Fed's target as the jobs market continued to improve.\n\nA reduction in the Fed's assets -- mostly U.S. Treasury and mortgage-backed securities -- is expected to help push up mortgage and other longer-term interest rates.\n\nThe bond purchases caused the amount of assets on the Fed's balance sheet to more than quadruple since 2008. The Fed stopped buying bonds in 2014 but the size of its holdings has remained roughly the same because the money from maturing securities has been reinvested in new ones.\n\nThe Fed is planning to slowly decrease the size of its holdings by allowing some of the proceeds from maturing bonds to be cashed out instead of reinvested.\n\nTwitter: @JimPuzzanghera\n\njim.puzzanghera@latimes.com", {"sim": 0.7764706015586853, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9160597", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "canadianbusiness.com", "title": "Canadian Business", "id": "3724"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 4723, "textEnd": 4731, "date": "2017-09-20", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.canadianbusiness.com/business-news/top-fed-official-warns-bond-portfolio-could-shrink-soon/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:58:00", "title": "Top Fed official warns bond portfolio could shrink soon - Canadian Business - Your Source For Business News", "uri": "709440630", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:58:00Z", "time": "20:58:00", "body": "A top Federal Reserve official suggested Monday that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio -- a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nIn an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin selling some of those bonds.\n\nDudley also said that he would favour a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans. He noted that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 per cent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 per cent target rate -- a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline. In its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 per cent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nOn other topics, Dudley:\n\n_ Suggested that Gary Cohn, who leads President Donald Trump's National Economic Council and is close to Trump, would be a \"reasonable candidate\" to succeed Yellen as Fed chair if Trump chooses not to re-nominate Yellen when her term ends early next year. Dudley, who worked with Cohn as top officials at Goldman Sachs, said Cohn \"knows a lot about financial markets,\" and \"I don't think you have to have a Ph.D. in economics\" to lead the Fed. In a recent interview, Trump said he was considering both Yellen and Cohn for the top Fed job, along with some other candidates he would not name.\n\n_ Expressed confidence that the Fed's political independence, long considered essential for it to carry out its functions, would remain respected during a Trump presidency. Trump may have the opportunity to install up to five members of the Fed's seven-member board over the next year, and the president has shown a tendency to expect loyalty from some people he has named to key positions. Trump had offered a harsh judgment of the Fed and of Yellen during the presidential campaign but has since avoided making critical comments. Dudley noted that the Trump administration has so far been \"very hands-off\" toward the Fed, \"very respectful of the monetary policy.\"\n\n_ Said that even as stock prices set record highs and other assets surge as well, he isn't concerned that any potentially devastating asset bubbles might be forming, akin to the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 crisis. Dudley said asset prices \"are pretty consistent with what we are seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy,\" which he said has been evolving without much volatility.\n\n_Acknowledged that policymakers need to be \"somewhat humble\" about how the forthcoming reduction in the Fed's bond portfolio might affect financial markets and loan rates. Dudley noted that the Fed has never before had to pare a balance sheet that has grown five-fold to $4.5 trillion. But he said officials have learned from the 2013 \"taper tantrum\" that rocked markets after a surprise announcement from the Fed, and has sought to telegraph all its actions well in advance.\n\nThe Fed's announcement that it will start paring its bond portfolio is expected to come after its next policy meeting ends Sept. 20. The meeting after that, in December, is when many Fed watchers expect the next increase in its key short-term rate, which remains in a still-low range of 1 per cent to 1.25 per cent.\n\nYellen and other Fed officials have attributed the persistently low inflation rate, which slowed further in recent months, to such transitory events as a sharp drop in cellphone fees.\n\nDudley said that if the economy evolves during the rest of 2017 as he expects, with inflation rebounding, \"I would be in favour of doing another rate hike later this year.\"\n\nFollow us on Facebook Follow us on Twitter\n\nGet our daily briefing on innovation, leadership, technology & the economy.\n\nWeekdays at 6 AM ET. Others expressed concerns that delaying further rate hikes could push inflation higher into dangerous territory.\n\nThe policy debate was revealed in minutes released Wednesday of the Fed's July 25-26 meeting. Officials eventually made a unanimous decision to keep its key policy rate unchanged.\n\nThe minutes also showed that several officials pushed for a July announcement that the Fed was ready to start reducing its massive bond holdings, a move that would likely mean slightly higher rates on mortgages and some other loans. Policymakers decided in the end to signal that it would come \"relatively soon.\"\n\nFinancial markets expect that announcement at next month's meeting, but analysts do not expect the Fed's next rate hike to come until December at the earliest. The latest reading of traders' expectations shows less than a 50-50 chance of a December hike, according to the CME Group. If inflation does not start moving higher again, they say it is likely the Fed will keep rates unchanged until next year.\n\nAt the July meeting, officials voted to keep the Fed's benchmark rate unchanged in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The Fed had raised rates at its March and June meetings even though inflation this year has slowed and is now further from the Fed's 2 percent goal than it was at the start of the year. In June, the Fed continued to signal that it expected to raise rates one more time this year.\n\nIn their July discussion, the minutes showed that some officials expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation, even though unemployment has continued to decline. It is currently at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent.\n\nOfficials worried about low inflation said that the Fed should delay any further rate hikes until it had greater assurance that the slowdown stemmed from temporary factors and that prices would climb more quickly in coming months.\n\nBut other officials worried that with the labor market already at full employment, waiting too long to raise rates again ran the risk of overshooting on the 2 percent inflation target. That would be \"costly to reverse,\" meaning that the Fed would have to raise rates more quickly and higher in the future, actions that could push the economy into a recession.\n\nThe inflation debate explored a number of issues, the minutes showed, including the possibility that long-held views on the relationship between tight labor markets and higher inflation may no longer be valid.", "date": {"sim": 0.7490196228027344, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9556401", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "foxbusiness.com", "title": "Fox Business", "id": "1702"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 305, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 315, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3820, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 3835, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1287, "textEnd": 1294, "date": "2017-08-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2017/08/16/fed-officials-split-over-next-rate-increase.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:06:00", "title": "Fed Officials Split Over Next Rate Increase", "uri": "710521584", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T16:33:00Z", "time": "16:33:00", "body": "Federal Reserve officials meeting in July split over the timing of future interest rate increases as they struggled to understand why inflation has been so weak in recent months. But they agreed to soon begin the years-long process of drawing down the central bank's holdings, according to minutes of the July 25-26 meeting released Wednesday after the customary three-week lag.\n\nSagging inflation led some officials to suggest holding off on raising rates again for now, arguing the Fed \"could afford to be patient under current circumstances.\"\n\nOthers, however, worried that the strong labor market and high stock prices could produce a spurt of inflation above the central bank's 2% target that could be difficult to control. This group cautioned that waiting too long to raise rates \"could result in an overshooting of the [Fed's] inflation objective that would likely be costly to reverse,\" the minutes said.\n\nThe minutes could raise doubts about the prospects of another increase in the Fed's benchmark interest rate by year's end. The central bank has raised rates twice this year and penciled in a third rate increase in 2017 as well as three in 2018.\n\nFed officials have been publically airing their disagreement over the proper course of interest rates since the meeting.\n\nOn. Aug. 11, Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan said he wants to see \"more evidence\" of progress towards the inflation goal before he'll support another rate increase, adding that the current 1% to 1.25% range for the Fed's benchmark short-term interest rate was \"appropriate.\" He spoke a day after Chicago Fed President Charles Evans urged officials to \"be very careful in assessing the future [rate] moves.\"\n\nNew York Fed President William Dudley, on the other hand, said in an interview with the Associated Press this week that he \"would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"\n\nThe split has left markets questioning a third rate increase in 2017. As of Wednesday morning, before the release of the minutes, investors saw a roughly 50% probability the Fed would leave rates unchanged through year's end.\n\nFed Chairwoman Janet Yellen could have a chance to weigh in at the Kansas City Fed's annual economic conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo., later this month.\n\nFed officials and economists have struggled over the past few years to reconcile booming job growth with weak price pressures. Under standard economic theory, a better labor market would lead to higher wages and consumer prices. That hasn't happened.\n\nSome officials in July said they thought the standard theory \"was not particularly useful,\" while others believed it remained valid. Puzzled policy makers talked through possible explanations for the disconnect, including possible structural changes in the labor market or imprecise data, according to the minutes.\n\nMs. Yellen,in Congressional testimony last month, said she believed inflation would move back to 2% over the next couple of years.\n\nData released since the meeting, however, showed inflation continues to weaken while the labor market continues to strengthen. Prices rose 1.4% in June over the previous year, down from 1.5% in May, according to the Fed's preferred inflation gauge. Meanwhile, employers added a healthy 209,000 jobs in July and the unemployment rate ticked down to 4.3%, matching the lowest level in 16 years.\n\nThe minutes also indicated that officials were confident their plans to slowly reduce their $4.5 trillion portfolio would run smoothly without disrupting markets. Some officials were ready to announce the start of the portfolio runoff in July but \"most preferred to defer that decision until an upcoming meeting\" in order to gather more information, the minutes said. Offcicials agreed that they should begin the process \"relatively soon.\"\n\nThe Fed next meets on September 19-20. In recent weeks, some Fed officials have said the September meeting would be an appropriate time to begin shrinking the balance sheet.\n\nIn the aftermath of the financial crisis, the Fed launched large-scale asset purchase programs that scooped up Treasury and mortgage-backed securities to lower long-term borrowing costs. Today, with the economy on a firmer footing, officials are ready to start unwinding those programs by letting a preset amount of securities mature every month. Officials haven't said when they'll begin or how much they are likely to shrink their portfolio.\n\nPolicy makers at the July meeting said they expected market reaction to the portfolio reduction process to be muted. Unwinding the asset purchase programs would \"contribute only modestly\" to tighter monetary policy, they said.\n\nEconomists at Goldman Sachs estimate shrinking the balance sheet will raise 10-year Treasury yields by 0.2 percentage point this year, 0.15 percentage point next year and 0.1 percentage point between 2019 and 2012.\n\nYields have been historically low in recent years, hovering below 2.3% for the past two weeks.\n\nThe July minutes also said that some Fed officials see a waning possibility that the Republican-held Congress and the Trump administration will manage to push through their ambitious plans for a tax overhaul and new infrastructure spending.", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": {"sim": 0.7411764860153198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9179237", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "title": "The Boston Globe", "id": "512"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.bostonglobe.com/rf/image_585w/Boston/2011-2020/2017/08/14/BostonGlobe.com/Business/Images/abd3cfbebbba4cc8892b3a9306907a66-91bcad82435a404a8f5e54575a81ee1f-0.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 4530, "textEnd": 4538, "date": "2017-09-20", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2017/08/14/top-fed-official-tells-bond-portfolio-could-shrink-soon/g08Q87BIYffoV0lSIWWSVM/story.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:33:00", "title": "Top Fed official tells AP: Bond portfolio could shrink soon - The Boston Globe", "uri": "709494019", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:33:00Z", "time": "23:33:00", "body": "NEW YORK -- A top Federal Reserve official suggested Monday that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio -- a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nIn an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin selling some of those bonds.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans. He noted that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\nGet Talking Points in your inbox: An afternoon recap of the day's most important business news, delivered weekdays. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here\n\n''The plan is out there,'' he said during an interview at the New York Fed. ''It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.''\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate -- a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline. In its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nOn other topics, Dudley:\n\n\u25a0 Suggested that Gary Cohn, who leads President Trump's National Economic Council and is close to Trump, would be a ''reasonable candidate'' to succeed Yellen as Fed chair if Trump chooses not to renominate Yellen when her term ends early next year. In a recent interview, Trump said he was considering both Yellen and Cohn for the top Fed job, along with some other candidates he would not name.\n\n\u25a0 Expressed confidence that the Fed's political independence, long considered essential for it to carry out its functions, would remain respected during a Trump presidency. Trump may have the opportunity to install up to five members of the Fed's seven-member board over the next year. Dudley noted that the Trump administration has so far been ''very hands-off'' toward the Fed, ''very respectful of the monetary policy.''\n\n\u25a0 Said that even as stock prices set record highs and other assets surge as well, he isn't concerned that any potentially devastating asset bubbles might be forming, akin to the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 crisis. Dudley said asset prices ''are pretty consistent with what we are seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy,'' which he said has been evolving without much volatility.\n\n\u25a0 Acknowledged that policy makers need to be ''somewhat humble'' about how the forthcoming reduction in the Fed's bond portfolio might affect financial markets and loan rates. Dudley noted that the Fed has never before had to pare a balance sheet that has grown five-fold to $4.5 trillion. But he said officials have learned from the 2013 ''taper tantrum'' that rocked markets after a surprise announcement from the Fed, and has sought to telegraph all its actions well in advance.\n\nThe Fed's announcement that it will start paring its bond portfolio is expected to come after its next policy meeting ends Sept. 20.", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri":
