{"sim": 0.7372549176216125, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9591683", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "startribune.com", "title": "Star Tribune", "id": "157"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://assets.startribune.com/static/img/branding/logos/strib-social-card.png?d=1502908689", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 909, "dateEnd": "2017-09-20", "imp": true, "textEnd": 924, "date": "2017-09-19", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.startribune.com/fed-leaders-divided-on-state-of-inflation-relative-to-possible-september-rate-hike/440845653/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:06:00", "title": "Fed leaders divided on state of inflation relative to possible September rate hike", "uri": "710621061", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T01:06:00Z", "time": "01:06:00", "body": "WASHINGTON - Federal Reserve officials are struggling to make sense of a new economic reality in which low inflation and low unemployment are persisting side by side.\n\nAt the Fed's most recent meeting, in late July, most officials said they expected the phenomenon to fade away by next year as low unemployment finally starts to drive up inflation.\n\nBut a growing number of officials see the pattern as proof that the Fed needs to adjust its assumptions, according to an account of the meeting that the Fed published on Wednesday.\n\nAt the July meeting, the Fed left its benchmark rate in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. It also said it planned to start reducing its asset holdings \"relatively soon.\" The minutes said some Fed officials were ready to announce a starting date for the reductions, but most favored just a little more patience. Analysts expect an announcement after the Fed's next meeting, Sept. 19 and 20.\n\nThe timing of the Fed's next rate move is considerably less certain. The Fed entered the year predicting three rate increases of a quarter-point each; so far it has delivered two, with a third seen possible in December.\n\nBut the weakness of inflation, which the Fed now expects to remain below its target annual pace of 2 percent for the fifth consecutive year, is prompting some Fed officials to hesitate.\n\nMost Fed officials subscribe to a view of inflation in which prices rise more quickly as unemployment declines. The basic idea is that companies must offer higher and higher wages to keep their workers.\n\nNow, the Fed is confronting \"the coexistence of low inflation and low unemployment,\" a phenomenon that inverts the \"stagflation\" experience of the 1970s, when both inflation and unemployment climbed.\n\nThe meeting account said most officials continued to regard low unemployment as the most important factor. They said inflation was rising slowly because of temporary factors, like a decline in cellphone prices. And they remain inclined to raise the Fed's benchmark rate later this year.\n\nBut as low inflation persists, alternative theories have blossomed. Some Fed officials see evidence that the low unemployment rate overstates the health of the job market, and therefore that the Fed should wait to raise interest rates.\n\nLow rates support job growth by encouraging borrowing and risk-taking.\n\nOthers see evidence that the connection between unemployment and inflation has been overstated.\n\nSome Fed officials have suggested that the public is losing confidence that the Fed will raise inflation back to a 2 percent annual pace, which could make it harder for the Fed to do so, because inflation expectations can become self-fulfilling.\n\nThe account said some voting members of the Fed's policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, wanted reassurance that inflation was rising before voting to raise rates again.\n\nThe slow pace of wage growth is driving a parallel debate. Wages have increased modestly in recent years, and the minutes noted again there was \"little evidence of wage pressures.\"\n\nSome officials see further confirmation that the economy is weak.\n\nOthers, however, see the data as misleading. One possibility, advanced by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, is that aggregate wage measures remain low because the baby boomers are retiring. In this view, older, high-wage workers are being replaced by younger workers who make less simply because they are at an earlier stage in their careers. That is holding down measures of average wages, but individual workers may still be seeing healthier wage growth.\n\nAnd there are also those who contend that wage growth is doing about as well as one would expect given the slow growth of productivity.\n\nFed officials continue to retreat from the expectation that the Trump administration will deliver a large dose of fiscal stimulus, whether in tax cuts or increased infrastructure spending. The Fed reported that companies, too, are losing hope.\n\n\"Uncertainty about the course of federal government policy, including in the areas of fiscal policy, trade and health care, was tending to weigh down firms' spending and hiring plans,\" the minutes said.\n\nThe Fed also included in the minutes a warning about the Trump administration's plans to reduce what it regards as overly burdensome financial regulation.\n\n\"It would not be desirable,\" the minutes said, \"for the current regulatory framework to be changed in ways that allowed a re-emergence of the types of risky practices that contributed to the crisis.\"", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100, "id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic"}, {"uri": "dmoz/News/Current_Events", "wgt": 100, "id": 265, "label": "dmoz/News/Current Events"}, {"uri": "dmoz/News/Current_Events/Business_and_Economy", "wgt": 100, "id": 266, "label": "dmoz/News/Current Events/Business and Economy"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business", "wgt": 100, "id": 268, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Business"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Marketing_and_Advertising/Advertising", "wgt": 100, "id": 779, "label": "dmoz/Business/Marketing and Advertising/Advertising"}], US inflation is one type of data that drives market expectations with regards to the Fed's action. Slowing inflation (TIP) has been a concern for the Fed and many FOMC members. More weakness in inflation could be mean a delay in rate hikes from the Fed. The Fed has raised interest rates three times this year. It's expected to increase interest rates one more time in 2017 and take the US interest rate from 1.25% to 1.50%. The Fed has termed the slowdown in growth and inflation (VTIP) in the first quarter as \"transitory.\" However, the Fed changed its tone in the recent meeting. The statement that was released after the July meeting indicated that it would take longer than expected to reach the 2% inflation goal that the Fed has set for itself.\n\nMarkets expected the inflation growth for July to be reported at 1.7% -- below the Fed's target rate of 2%. A steady decline in inflation has contributed to volatility (VXX) in the bond (BND) and currency markets (UUP). According to the fed funds futures, the probability of another rate hike this year is below 50%. The inflation report for July didn't revive the hopes for another rate hike this year.\n\nLower inflation will likely derail the Fed's plans on monetary tightening and could impact its plans to reduce the size of its balance sheet. The Fed would need more evidence in the form of improved inflation before it hikes rates again. I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"\n\nThe Fed has raised rates twice this year and aims, according to forecasts, to hike once more. However a slide in inflation readings in recent months to 1.5 percent, below a 2-percent Fed target, has raised doubts among investors who give about a 40 percent chance of the Fed following through.\n\nMore certain is the Fed's well-telegraphed plan to announce the start date for beginning to shed some of the bonds in its $4.5-trillion portfolio, most of which it amassed to spur the economy in the wake of the 2007-2009 crisis.\n\n\"I don't think the expectations of market participants are unreasonable,\" Dudley, who has a permanent vote on Fed policy, said when asked whether predictions were accurate for the plan to be announced at a mid-September meeting. He predicted the portfolio would shrink to between $2.5 and $3.5 trillion after five years.\n\nInvestors and economists generally expect the Fed next month to announce that bonds will begin to run off around October 1. That is the month that the Treasury is expected to fully exhaust its remaining borrowing capacity in what is known as the \"debt ceiling.\"\n\nThis does \"not really\" pose difficulties for the Fed because the debt it holds counts against the limit, and it could choose to \"delay the actual start date\" of reducing the portfolio, Dudley said.\n\nElsewhere in Washington, speculation has heated up over who President Donald Trump would pick as Fed chair, with the president himself saying his economic advisor Gary Cohn as well as Yellen, whose term expires in February, are contenders. Fed officials and congressional Democrats have worried that that and other vacancies would leave the door open for Republicans to trim the Fed's historic independence from politics.\n\nAsked about Cohn, Dudley said he is a \"reasonable candidate ... who knows a lot about financial markets.\" Both men are Goldman Sachs alumni: Cohn a president at the Wall Street bank and Dudley a partner.\n\n\"The Trump Administration has been very hands-off in terms of the Fed,\" Dudley added when asked about threats to independence. \"So, I think they've been very respectful of the monetary policy, not to politicize the monetary policy process.\"\n\nSEARCH", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": {"sim": 0.7254902124404907, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9280187", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "centralmaine.com", "title": "Central Maine", "id": "8208"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://multifiles.pressherald.com/uploads/sites/2/2017/08/1240508_Federal_Reserve-Dudley_In4.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.centralmaine.com/2017/08/14/top-fed-official-says-bond-portfolio-could-shrink-soon/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:58:00", "title": "Top Fed official says bond portfolio could shrink soon - CentralMaine.com", "uri": "709770457", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:58:00Z", "time": "12:58:00", "body": "Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK -- A top Federal Reserve official suggested Monday that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio - a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nWilliam Dudley Search photos available for purchase: Photo Store \u2192\n\nIn an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin trimming its bond holdings.\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans.\n\nDudley pointed out that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate - a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline.\n\nIn its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? {"sim": 0.7254902124404907, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9212297", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "sify.com", "title": "Sify", "id": "186"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "New York City"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://static.sify.com/cms/image/ripkFGbeejgij_small.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 1920, "textEnd": 1929, "date": "2017-10-01", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.sify.com/finance/dudley-tells-skeptical-markets-he-sees-fed-rate-hike-ap-news-policy-ripkFDbhbdbgc.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:24:00", "title": "Dudley tells skeptical markets he sees Fed rate hike: AP", "uri": "709587086", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T05:24:00Z", "time": "05:24:00", "body": "WASHINGTON/NEW YORK (Reuters) - One of the Federal Reserve's most influential members expects to raise interest rates once more this year, and to soon begin shedding some of the Fed's bond holdings, according to comments on Monday that pushed back on doubts in financial markets.\n\nIn an interview with the Associated Press, New York Fed President William Dudley, a close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen, also praised the Trump administration for not \"politicizing\" the U.S. central bank's decisions as some members of Congress have done in recent years.\n\nHis steady-as-she-goes comments on inflation and rates appeared to respond to growing skepticism in financial markets that the Fed will raise rates by December, and they prompted a rise in the dollar and in bond yields.\n\n\"It depends on how the economic forecast evolves,\" Dudley told the AP. \"If it evolves in line with my expectations ... I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"\n\nThe Fed has raised rates twice this year and aims, according to forecasts, to hike once more. However a slide in inflation readings in recent months to 1.5 percent, below a 2-percent Fed target, has raised doubts among investors who give about a 40 percent chance of the Fed following through.\n\nMore certain is the Fed's well-telegraphed plan to announce the start date for beginning to shed some of the bonds in its $4.5-trillion portfolio, most of which it amassed to spur the economy in the wake of the 2007-2009 crisis.\n\n\"I don't think the expectations of market participants are unreasonable,\" Dudley, who has a permanent vote on Fed policy, said when asked whether predictions were accurate for the plan to be announced at a mid-September meeting. He predicted the portfolio would shrink to between $2.5 and $3.5 trillion after five years.\n\nInvestors and economists generally expect the Fed next month to announce that bonds will begin to run off around October 1. That is the month that the Treasury is expected to fully exhaust its remaining borrowing capacity in what is known as the \"debt ceiling.\"\n\nThis does \"not really\" pose difficulties for the Fed because the debt it holds counts against the limit, and it could choose to \"delay the actual start date\" of reducing the portfolio, Dudley said.\n\nElsewhere in Washington, speculation has heated up over who President Donald Trump would pick as Fed chair, with the president himself saying his economic advisor Gary Cohn as well as Yellen, whose term expires in February, are contenders. Fed officials and congressional Democrats have worried that that and other vacancies would leave the door open for Republicans to trim the Fed's historic independence from politics.\n\nAsked about Cohn, Dudley said he is a \"reasonable candidate ... who knows a lot about financial markets.\" Both men are Goldman Sachs alumni: Cohn a president at the Wall Street bank and Dudley a partner.\n\n\"The Trump Administration has been very hands-off in terms of the Fed,\" Dudley added when asked about threats to independence. \"So, I think they've been very respectful of the monetary policy, not to politicize the monetary policy process.\"\n\n(Reporting by Jonathan Spicer and Lindsay Dunsmuir; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)\n\nSEARCH", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7215686440467834, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9181225", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "pressherald.com", "title": "Portland Press Herald", "id": "1378"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://multifiles.pressherald.com/uploads/sites/4/2017/08/1240508_Federal_Reserve-Dudley_In4.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.pressherald.com/2017/08/14/top-fed-official-says-bond-portfolio-could-shrink-soon/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:51:00", "title": "Top Fed official says bond portfolio could shrink soon - Portland Press Herald", "uri": "709498968", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T23:51:00Z", "time": "23:51:00", "body": "Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK -- A top Federal Reserve official suggested Monday that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio - a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nWilliam Dudley Search photos available for purchase: Photo Store \u2192\n\nIn an interview with The Associated Press, William Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. With the economy now much healthier, the Fed is ready to begin trimming its bond holdings.\n\nDudley also said that he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark short-term rate if the economy remained strong. Many investors expect a modest rate hike in December, to follow the Fed's previous increases in March and June this year.\n\nSpeaking of the Fed's likely September announcement that it will begin shrinking its $4.5 trillion bond portfolio, Dudley expressed confidence that investors would react calmly to the prospect of modestly higher rates on some consumer and business loans.\n\nDudley pointed out that the Fed spelled out to investors months ago the system it plans to use to reduce the portfolio gradually.\n\n\"The plan is out there,\" he said during an interview at the New York Fed. \"It's been generally well-received and fully anticipated. People expect it to take place.\"\n\nAs president of the Fed's New York regional bank, Dudley is an influential voice on interest-rate policy. He is vice chairman of the central bank's policy panel that sets interest rates and is a longtime close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen.\n\nHis interview with the AP comes at a time when the Fed has essentially met one of its two mandates: To maximize employment. The unemployment rate is at a 16-year low of 4.3 percent, and job growth remains consistently solid.\n\nYet the Fed has so far failed to meet its second objective of keeping prices stable. Inflation has stayed chronically below the Fed's 2 percent target rate - a problem because consumers often delay purchases when they think prices will stay the same or even decline.\n\nIn its latest reading, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge was just 1.4 percent year over year. Dudley said Monday that he still thinks inflation will rise toward the Fed's target level as the job market strengthens further and sluggish wage growth begins to pick up.\n\nShare\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nWant the news vital to Maine? Our daily headlines email is delivered each morning. Email* Newsletter Choices* Daily Headlines Breaking News Business Headlines High School Sports Real Estate * I understand the Terms of Service. {"sim": 0.7137255072593689, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9155079", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 72, "textEnd": 78, "date": "2017-08-14", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1979, "textEnd": 1988, "date": "2017-10-01", "amb": false}], "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/dudley-tells-skeptical-markets-he-sees-fed-rate-hike-ap/articleshow/60066404.cms", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:15:00", "title": "Dudley tells skeptical markets he sees Fed rate hike -AP - Times of India", "uri": "709424576", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:15:00Z", "time": "20:15:00", "body": "(Adds market reaction, context, comments on Cohn)\n\nWASHINGTON/NEW YORK, Aug 14 (Reuters) - One of the Federal Reserve's most influential members expects to raise interest rates once more this year, and to soon begin shedding some of the Fed's bond holdings, according to comments on Monday that pushed back on doubts in financial markets.\n\nIn an interview with the Associated Press, New York Fed President William Dudley, a close ally of Fed Chair Janet Yellen, also praised the Trump administration for not \"politicizing\" the U.S. central bank's decisions as some members of Congress have done in recent years.\n\nHis steady-as-she-goes comments on inflation and rates appeared to respond to growing skepticism in financial markets that the Fed will raise rates by December, and they prompted a rise in the dollar and in bond yields.\n\n\"It depends on how the economic forecast evolves,\" Dudley told the AP. \"If it evolves in line with my expectations ... I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year.\"\n\nThe Fed has raised rates twice this year and aims, according to forecasts, to hike once more. However a slide in inflation readings in recent months to 1.5 percent, below a 2-percent Fed target, has raised doubts among investors who give about a 40 percent chance of the Fed following through.\n\nMore certain is the Fed's well-telegraphed plan to announce the start date for beginning to shed some of the bonds in its $4.5-trillion portfolio, most of which it amassed to spur the economy in the wake of the 2007-2009 crisis.\n\n\"I don't think the expectations of market participants are unreasonable,\" Dudley, who has a permanent vote on Fed policy, said when asked whether predictions were accurate for the plan to be announced at a mid-September meeting. He predicted the portfolio would shrink to between $2.5 and $3.5 trillion after five years.\n\nInvestors and economists generally expect the Fed next month to announce that bonds will begin to run off around October 1. That is the month that the Treasury is expected to fully exhaust its remaining borrowing capacity in what is known as the \"debt ceiling.\"\n\nThis does \"not really\" pose difficulties for the Fed because the debt it holds counts against the limit, and it could choose to \"delay the actual start date\" of reducing the portfolio, Dudley said.\n\nElsewhere in Washington, speculation has heated up over who President Donald Trump would pick as Fed chair, with the president himself saying his economic advisor Gary Cohn as well as Yellen, whose term expires in February, are contenders. Fed officials and congressional Democrats have worried that that and other vacancies would leave the door open for Republicans to trim the Fed's historic independence from politics.\n\nAsked about Cohn, Dudley said he is a \"reasonable candidate ... who knows a lot about financial markets.\" Both men are Goldman Sachs alumni: Cohn a president at the Wall Street bank and Dudley a partner.\n\n\"The Trump Administration has been very hands-off in terms of the Fed,\" Dudley added when asked about threats to independence. \"So, I think they've been very respectful of the monetary policy, not to politicize the monetary policy process.\"\n\n(Reporting by Jonathan Spicer and Lindsay Dunsmuir; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with [{"textStart": 338, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 348, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.enca.com/money/us-fed-can-be-patient-in-raising-rates-minutes", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:04:00", "title": "US Fed can 'be patient' in raising rates: minutes", "uri": "710635491", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T17:33:00Z", "time": "17:33:00", "body": "WASHINGTON - US central bankers remain divided over inflation risks, and some argue they can afford to \"be patient\" before raising rates again, according to the minutes of the last policy meeting released Wednesday.\n\nThe Federal Reserve had been expected to raise the benchmark lending rate a third time this year, but the minutes of the July 25-26 meeting showed policymakers remained befuddled by weak inflation that has persisted despite historically low unemployment.\n\nBut members of the Federal Open Market Committee agreed the Fed could announce \"relatively soon\" the start of planned efforts to reduce the central bank's multi-trillion-dollar investment holdings, a move that will effectively raise borrowing costs.\n\nAmid steady job creation and the falling jobless rate, many Fed officials continue to dismiss weak price pressures, blaming them on \"idiosyncratic\" factors, such as falling prices for mobile phone plans and medications.\n\nBut after raising the key interest rate twice this year, monetary policymakers have found themselves hard pressed to explain the absence of inflation, as closely-watched measures have remained weak or even retreated from the Fed's two percent target.\n\nThe minutes showed Fed members were increasingly torn in different directions, with some believing the current era of low inflation could last well into the future.\n\nThose pointing to low inflation said the central bank should \"be patient\" before adopting its next rate hike \"until incoming information confirmed that the recent low readings on inflation were not likely to persist.\"\n\nBut other participants feared that persistently low-interest rates could create instability and spur risk taking in financial markets.\n\nFed members generally believe inflation will remain low through the second half of this year, with many expecting the rate to stabilize \"over the next couple of years from its current low,\" according to the minutes.\n\nHowever, others \"saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below two percent for longer than they currently expected,\" the minutes said.\n\nThe minutes also confirmed expectations that the central bank as soon as its next meeting in September could announce the start of a process of drawing down its $4.5 trillion asset holdings.\n\nThe Fed bought huge amounts of bonds to support the financial markets during the 2008 crisis, which had a similar effect as rate cuts and has been working for months on a plan to gradually reduce investment holdings without roiling markets.\n\nFed members generally agreed that given their belief, the US economy likely will continue its economic recovery, it was \"appropriate to signal\" the program \"likely would begin relatively soon.\"", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services", "wgt": 100, "id": 100, "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services"}, {"uri": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 501, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4797022/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:43:00", "title": "US Fed can 'be patient' in raising rates: minutes", "uri": "710510335", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T19:43:00Z", "time": "19:43:00", "body": "Federal Reserve members are divided over the outlook for inflation, but some say the central bank can afford to wait before raising the benchmark lending rate again\n\nUS central bankers remain divided over inflation risks, and some argue they can afford to \"be patient\" before raising rates again, according to the minutes of the last policy meeting released Wednesday.\n\nThe Federal Reserve had been expected to raise the benchmark lending rate a third time this year, but the minutes of the July 25-26 meeting showed policymakers remained befuddled by weak inflation that has persisted despite historically low unemployment.\n\nBut members of the Federal Open Market Committee agreed the Fed could announce \"relatively soon\" the start of planned efforts to reduce the central bank's multi-trillion-dollar investment holdings, a move that will effectively raise borrowing costs.\n\nAmid steady job creation and the falling jobless rate, many Fed officials continue to dismiss weak price pressures, blaming them on \"idiosyncratic\" factors, such as falling prices for mobile phone plans and medications.\n\nBut after raising the key interest rate twice this year, monetary policymakers have found themselves hard pressed to explain the absence of inflation, as closely-watched measures have remained weak or even retreated from the Fed's two percent target.\n\nThe minutes showed Fed members were increasingly torn in different directions, with some believing the current era of low inflation could last well into the future.\n\nThose pointing to low inflation said the central bank should \"be patient\" before adopting its next rate hike \"until incoming information confirmed that the recent low readings on inflation were not likely to persist.\"\n\nBut other participants feared that persistently low interest rates could create instability and spur risk taking in financial markets.\n\nFed members generally believe inflation will remain low through the second half of this year, with many expecting the rate to stabilize \"over the next couple of years from its current low,\" according to the minutes.\n\nHowever, others \"saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below two percent for longer than they currently expected,\" the minutes said.\n\nThe minutes also confirmed expectations that the central bank as soon as its next meeting in September could announce the start of a process of drawing down its $4.5 trillion asset holdings.\n\nThe Fed bought huge amounts of bonds to support the financial markets during the 2008 crisis, which had a similar effect as rate cuts, and has been working for months on a plan to gradually reduce investment holdings without roiling markets.\n\nFed members generally agreed that, given their belief the US economy likely will {"sim": 0.6980392336845398, "details": {"liCnt": 8}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9172084", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "bloomberg.com", "title": "Bloomberg Business", "id": "1749"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://assets.bwbx.io/images/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/i4DRT5GDIzrY/v0/1200x800.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 2453, "textEnd": 2460, "date": "2017-07-26", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-14/fed-s-dudley-says-he-still-favors-another-rate-increase-in-2017", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:27:00", "title": "Fed's Dudley Says He Still Favors Another Rate Hike in 2017", "uri": "709473908", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:43:00Z", "time": "17:43:00", "body": "New York Fed chief sees inflation picking up in coming months\n\nFederal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley said it isn't unreasonable to expect the central bank to announce plans in September to start trimming its balance sheet and said he supports another interest-rate increase this year if the economy evolves as he expects.\n\n\"I would expect -- I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year\" if the economy holds up, Dudley said, speaking in an interview with the Associated Press.\n\nExpectations for a September announcement on when the Fed will begin to wind down its balance sheet weren't \"unreasonable,\" he said. A political debate over the debt ceiling is unlikely to have a \"big impact\" on that timetable because the central bank could announce the start of the program but delay the actual date.\n\n\"The plan is out there. It's been, I think, generally well-received, and fully anticipated,\" Dudley said of the outline for drawing down the $4.5 trillion balance sheet. \"In the last FOMC statement, we said that we expected this to happen relatively soon. So, I expect it to happen relatively soon.\"\n\nDudley's comments signal optimism at a time when inflation remains below the Fed's goal even as the labor market continues to expand and the overall economy is chugging along. The New York Fed chief brushed aside recent weak price data as a trend that will probably reverse, suggesting officials might be willing to look past the slowdown even as it becomes more sustained.\n\n\"We do expect as the labor market continues to tighten, to see firmer wage gains and that will ultimately filter into inflation moving up towards our 2 percent objective,\" Dudley said. \"A pretty broad range of evidence that suggests the labor market is quite a bit tighter than it's been in many years. Which is a good thing.\"\n\nFed officials have been projecting one more rate increase in 2017, for a total of three this year, but weak price gains have made markets doubt that outlook. Investors are pricing in just a 29 percent chance of a rate increase by year-end.\n\nThe U.S. has seen an extended run of sub-par inflation prints, the July Consumer Price Index reading showed last week. The Fed's preferred gauge, which comes out with a longer delay, was running at 1.4 percent in June -- well below the Fed's 2 percent goal.\n\nStill, Dudley's comments jibe with the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee's post-meeting statement on July 26, which said price gains were expected to \"stabilize around the Committee's 2 percent objective over the medium term.\" The Fed is scheduled to release minutes from that meeting this week, an account that could give a more textured glimpse into the inflation discussion.\n\n\"The jury's out of whether there is sort of structural, secular changes in place that are holding inflation lower on a sustained basis,\" Dudley said. \"The next four to six months I think are going to be important to see whether the readings that we've had over the last few months are mainly due to one-off factors, such as the big decline that we've seen in cellphone prices, or whether there's something more fundamental going on.\"\n\nDudley said if secular forces are pushing inflation lower, it's possible that the unemployment rate could fall further before it precipitates higher wages and prices.\n\nThe jobless rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, down from 4.7 percent headed into the year and below policy makers' estimate of the longer-run sustainable rate. The median official expected U.S. joblessness to average 4.3 percent in the fourth quarter and hold around 4.6 percent in the longer term, according to quarterly projections updated in June.\n\nThe New York Fed chief also brushed aside concerns about high asset prices, saying he's \"not particularly concerned,\" primarily because \"asset prices are pretty consistent with what we're seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy.\" When asked about his impression of White House economic adviser Gary Cohn as Fed chairman, he said \"I don't want to evaluate the various candidates for the Federal Reserve, except to say that I think Gary is a reasonable candidate.\"\n\nDudley, 64, has been President of the New York Fed since 2009 and was formerly chief U.S. economist at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. He holds a Ph.D. in economics from the University of California Berkeley.", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": {"sim": 0.6941176652908325, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9542755", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "title": "Washington Examiner", "id": "2955"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://cdn.washingtonexaminer.biz/cache/1060x600-d3d8458fde5843680b2dd94eb5630291.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 191, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 201, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/fed-likely-to-begin-reversing-crisis-era-stimulus-next-month-meeting-notes-suggest/article/2631729", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:34:00", "title": "Fed likely to begin reversing crisis-era stimulus next month, meeting notes suggest", "uri": "710484501", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:34:00Z", "time": "18:34:00", "body": "Federal Reserve officials are prepared to begin reversing the central bank's major crisis-era stimulus measures next month, notes from their July meeting published Wednesday suggest.\n\nAt the July 25-26 meeting, several Fed members were prepared to begin shrinking the central bank's balance sheet, the new minutes from the meeting revealed. Most preferred to defer the decision until a later meeting.\n\nWhile the group was mostly on the same page regarding the Fed's bond holdings, it was split on the timing of future interest rate hikes.\n\nRobust job growth this year has emboldened Chairwoman Janet Yellen and others at the Fed to begin shrinking the large balance sheet they built up through successive rounds of bond purchases, commonly referred to as quantitative easing.\n\nThe Fed has just under $4.5 trillion in bonds, mostly Treasury and mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Before the crisis, the central bank had just less than $900 billion in assets, but it went on several bond-buying spreesto increase the amount of money in private hands and boost economy-wide spending.\n\nIn theory, shrinking the balance sheet would have the opposite effect and would slow spending. From the Fed's perspective, such an anti-stimulus would be desirable because the greater danger to the economy now is too-high inflation, rather than high unemployment. With the nation's unemployment rate at 4.3 percent, officials believe that wages and prices must rise soon, forcing the Fed to tighten monetary policy to stave off higher inflation.\n\nAt the same time, though, the Fed is moving tentatively. Yellen and company have said that they will start by shrinking the balance sheet by just $10 billion a month, eventually ramping up to $50 billion. And they don't plan to sell bonds, but rather allow existing bonds to mature without reinvesting the proceeds in new securities.\n\nSeveral Fed members have played down the impact of slowly shrinking the balance sheet. As a group, they had not spelled out before Wednesday just how much they might reduce the central bank's holdings. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley suggested in an interview with the Associated Press this week that he might favor a balance sheet of $2.5 trillion to $3.5 trillion.\n\nThe bigger issue, in the eyes of Fed members, is what the central bank does with its short-term interest rate target. Currently set at 1 percent to 1.25 percent, the target influences rates on financial products throughout the economy, such as business loans, mortgages and credit cards. Higher rates should translate to lower spending and inflation.\n\nBefore Wednesday's meeting, investors saw a roughly fifty-fifty chance that the Fed might raise rates again this year.\n\nSome members of the Fed, however, questioned the premise that falling unemployment will inevitable yield higher inflation. A few suggested that the relationship between unemployment and inflation, known to economists as the Phillips Curve, \"was not particularly useful in forecasting inflation.\"\n\nYet \"most\" participants still believe in the Phillips Curve, the minutes revealed. In their assessment of the economy today, inflation is only running below the Fed's 2 percent target because of one-time factors, such as the steep drop in the price of cell phone service thanks to competition among carriers to offer unlimited data plans. In time, they think, inflation is bound to rise.\n\nAt July's meeting, Fed members also discussed the new post-crisis banking rules, and the efforts by the Trump administration and the congressional GOP to roll some of them back. They unanimously agreed that the new regulations on banks have made the financial system safer, and \"that it would not be desirable for the current regulatory framework to be changed in ways that allowed a reemergence of the types of risky practices that contributed to the crisis.\"", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Finance", "wgt": 100, "id": 324, {"sim": 0.6901960968971252, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9568882", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "brecorder.com", "title": "Business Recorder", "id": "1214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.brecorder.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/us-flag-1024.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 337, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 347, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/17/365201/us-can-be-patient-in-raising-rates-fed-members-say/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:37:00", "title": "US can 'be patient' in raising rates, Fed members say | Business Recorder", "uri": "710556528", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T21:37:00Z", "time": "21:37:00", "body": "WASHINGTON: US central bankers remain divided over inflation risks, and some argue they can afford to \"be patient\" before raising rates again, according to the minutes of the last policy meeting released Wednesday.\n\nThe Federal Reserve had been expected to raise the benchmark lending rate a third time this year, but the minutes of the July 25-26 meeting showed policymakers remained befuddled by weak inflation, despite historically low unemployment.\n\nThe minutes indicated the Fed could announce \"relatively soon\" the start of efforts to reduce the central bank's multi-trillion-dollar investment holdings.\n\nThey also showed Fed some members increasingly believed an era of inflation was settling in for the long haul, leaving policymakers increasingly torn in different directions.\n\nAmid steady job creation and the falling jobless rate, the Fed has dismissed weak price pressures, blaming them on one-off \"transitory\" and \"idiosyncratic\" factors, such as falling mobile phone plan and medication prices.\n\nBut after raising rates twice this year, with a third increase expected before the end of 2017, policymakers have found themselves hard pressed to explain the absence of inflation. Over the second quarter, inflation measures have remained weak or even retreated.\n\nOn one hand, some meeting participants feared that persistently low interest rates could create financial instability and spur risk taking. Others believed the low inflation justified allowing the economy to run hotter before hiking again.\n\nAs a group, Fed members generally believe inflation will remain low through the second half of 2017, with many believing it will stabilize \"over the next couple of years from its current low,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"Many participants, however, saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below two percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the minutes said.\n\n- The dollar nosedives -\n\nThose pointing to low inflation said the central bank should \"be patient\" before adopting its next rate hike \"until incoming information confirmed that the recent low readings on inflation were not likely to persist.\"\n\nFed members were again concerned by the dizzying heights to which Wall Street has risen since President Trump prevailed in November's presidential elections, suggesting too much easy money had encouraged market speculators.\n\n\"The staff warning about asset prices is hawkish, but the doves carried the day in July,\" Chris Low of FTN Financial said in a client note.\n\nThe minutes also suggested that as soon as its next meeting in September the central bank could announce the start of a process of drawing down its $4.5 trillion asset holdings, ending a stimulus policy put in place after the 2008 financial crisis.\n\nSince then, the Fed has used the returns on investments in government bonds to purchase yet more bonds but policymakers decided earlier this year the time was ripe for the policy to come to an end.\n\nFed members generally agreed that, given their belief the US economy would likely continue its economic recovery, \"it was appropriate to signal that implementation of the program likely would begin relatively soon.\"\n\nThe minutes' release coincided with Wednesday's collapse of White House business advisory councils, which were scrapped by President Trump in the wake of several high-profile resignations following his comments on a white supremacist rally in Virginia that turned violent.\n\nThe two events sent the US dollar tumbling on exchange markets, with the Dollar Index losing 0.3 percent over the prior day's close shortly after 1900 GMT.\n\n\"The Fed's growing concern about low inflation suggests officials would proceed cautiously in raising borrowing rates in the months ahead which could potentially scupper plans to hike again before year-end,\" Joe Manimbo of Western Union Business Solutions said in a research note.", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services", "wgt": 100, "id": 100, "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services"}, {"uri": {"sim": 0.6901960968971252, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9545971", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "title": "The New York Times", "id": "91"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://static01.nyt.com/images/2017/08/17/business/17dc-fed-3/17dc-fed-3-videoSixteenByNineJumbo1600.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/16/business/economy/federal-reserve-minutes.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:55:00", "title": "Fed Officials Confront New Reality: Low Inflation and Low Unemployment", "uri": "710493579", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:55:00Z", "time": "18:55:00", "body": "The timing of the Fed's next rate move is considerably less certain. The Fed entered the year predicting three rate increases of a quarter-point each; so far it has delivered two, with a third seen possible in December.\n\nBut the weakness of inflation, which the Fed now expects to remain below its target annual pace of 2 percent for the fifth-consecutive year, is prompting some Fed officials to hesitate.\n\nMost Fed officials subscribe to a view of inflation in which prices rise more quickly as unemployment declines. The basic idea is that companies must offer higher and higher wages to keep their workers.\n\nNow, the Fed is confronting \"the coexistence of low inflation and low unemployment,\" a phenomenon that inverts the \"stagflation\" experience of the 1970s, when both inflation and unemployment climbed.\n\nThe meeting account said most officials continued to regard low unemployment as the most important factor. They said inflation was rising slowly because of temporary factors, like a decline in cellphone prices. And they remain inclined to raise the Fed's benchmark rate later this year.\n\nBut as low inflation persists, alternative theories have blossomed. Some Fed officials see evidence that the low unemployment rate overstates the health of the job market, and therefore that the Fed should wait to raise interest rates. Low rates support job growth by encouraging borrowing and risk-taking.\n\nOthers see evidence that the connection between unemployment and inflation has been overstated.\n\nSome Fed officials have suggested that the public is losing confidence that the Fed will raise inflation back to a 2 percent annual pace, which could make it harder for the Fed to do so, because inflation expectations can become self-fulfilling.\n\nThe account said some voting members of the Fed's policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, wanted reassurance that inflation was rising before voting to raise rates again.\n\nThe slow pace of wage growth is driving a parallel debate. Wages have increased modestly in recent years, and the minutes noted again there was \"little evidence of wage pressures.\"\n\nSome officials see further confirmation that the economy is weak.\n\nOthers, however, see the data as misleading. One possibility, advanced by the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, is that aggregate wage measures remain low because the baby boomers are retiring. In this view, older, high-wage workers are being replaced by younger workers who make less simply because they are at an earlier stage in their careers. That is holding down measures of average wages, but individual workers may still be seeing healthier wage growth.\n\nAnd there are also those who contend that wage growth is doing about as well as one would expect given the slow growth of productivity.\n\nFed officials continue to retreat from the expectation that the Trump administration will deliver a large dose of fiscal stimulus, whether in tax cuts or increased infrastructure spending. The Fed reported that companies, too, are losing hope.\n\n\"Uncertainty about the course of federal government policy, including in the areas of fiscal policy, trade and health care, was tending to weigh down firms' spending and hiring plans,\" the minutes said.\n\nThe Fed also included in the minutes a warning about the Trump administration's plans to reduce what it regards as overly burdensome financial regulation.\n\n\"It would not be desirable,\" the minutes said, \"for the current regulatory framework to be changed in ways that allowed a re-emergence of the types of risky practices that contributed to the crisis.\"", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100, "id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Work", "wgt": 100, "id": {"sim": 0.686274528503418, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9172087", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "standardrepublic.com", "title": "Standard Republic", "id": "18909"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/1502735904613.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.standardrepublic.com/2017/08/fed-could-shrink-portfolio-soon-new-york-feds-william-dudley/23486.htm", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:27:00", "title": "Fed could shrink portfolio soon: New York Fed's William Dudley - Standard Republic", "uri": "709473930", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:43:00Z", "time": "18:43:00", "body": "A top Federal Reserve official is sending another signal that the central bank will soon begin to downsize its $4.5 trillion portfolio.\n\nNew York Federal Reserve President William Dudley suggested that the Fed will likely announce next month that it will begin paring its bond portfolio -- a step that could lead to slightly higher rates on mortgages and other loans.\n\nThe remarks come just a week after Charles Evans, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said it would be \"quite reasonable\" for the Fed to take action at its September meeting.\n\nDudley says he thinks the Fed has adequately prepared investors for a reduction in the portfolio, which swelled after the 2008 financial crisis as the Fed bought bonds to reduce long-term rates. Dudley also says he would favor a third increase this year in the Fed's benchmark rate if the economy remains strong. Many investors expect a rate hike in December.\n\nEvans said last week a rate hike could be delayed to 2018 if the Fed needs more time to evaluate whether inflation is on track to meet a 2% target.\n\nEconomists mostly expect the Fed to cut its balance sheet in September, citing a stronger U.S. economy and a recent uptick in hiring. The central bank will start by shedding up to $6 billion in government bonds and $4 billion in mortgage-backed securities each month. It plans on gradually raising the cap every quarter.", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services", "wgt": 100, "id": 100, "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial {"sim": 0.686274528503418, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9591178", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "news.abs-cbn.com", "title": "ABS-CBN News", "id": "1007"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://sa.kapamilya.com/absnews/abscbnnews/media/2017/news/08/17/fed.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 338, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 351, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}], "url": "http://news.abs-cbn.com/business/08/17/17/us-can-be-patient-in-raising-rates-fed-members-say", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:59:00", "title": "US can 'be patient' in raising rates, Fed members say", "uri": "710619426", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T00:59:00Z", "time": "00:59:00", "body": "WASHINGTON - US central bankers remain divided over inflation risks, and some argue they can afford to \"be patient\" before raising rates again, according to the minutes of the last policy meeting released Wednesday.\n\nThe Federal Reserve had been expected to raise the benchmark lending rate a third time this year, but the minutes of the July 25 to 26 meeting showed policymakers remained befuddled by weak inflation, despite historically low unemployment.\n\nThe minutes indicated the Fed could announce \"relatively soon\" the start of efforts to reduce the central bank's multi-trillion-dollar investment holdings.\n\nThey also showed Fed some members increasingly believed an era of inflation was settling in for the long haul, leaving policymakers increasingly torn in different directions.\n\nAmid steady job creation and the falling jobless rate, the Fed has dismissed weak price pressures, blaming them on one-off \"transitory\" and \"idiosyncratic\" factors, such as falling mobile phone plan and medication prices.\n\nBut after raising rates twice this year, with a third increase expected before the end of 2017, policymakers have found themselves hard pressed to explain the absence of inflation. Over the second quarter, inflation measures have remained weak or even retreated.\n\nOn one hand, some meeting participants feared that persistently low interest rates could create financial instability and spur risk taking. Others believed the low inflation justified allowing the economy to run hotter before hiking again.\n\nAs a group, Fed members generally believe inflation will remain low through the second half of 2017, with many believing it will stabilize \"over the next couple of years from its current low,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"Many participants, however, saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below two percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the minutes said.\n\nTHE DOLLAR NOSEDIVES\n\nThose pointing to low inflation said the central bank should \"be patient\" before adopting its next rate hike \"until incoming information confirmed that the recent low readings on inflation were not likely to persist.\"\n\nFed members were again concerned by the dizzying heights to which Wall Street has risen since President Trump prevailed in November's presidential elections, suggesting too much easy money had encouraged market speculators.\n\n\"The staff warning about asset prices is hawkish, but the doves carried the day in July,\" Chris Low of FTN Financial said in a client note.\n\nThe minutes also suggested that as soon as its next meeting in September the central bank could announce the start of a process of drawing down its $4.5 trillion asset holdings, ending a stimulus policy put in place after the 2008 financial crisis.\n\nSince then, the Fed has used the returns on investments in government bonds to purchase yet more bonds but policymakers decided earlier this year the time was ripe for the policy to come to an end.\n\nFed members generally agreed that, given their belief the US economy would likely continue its economic recovery, \"it was appropriate to signal that implementation of the program likely would begin relatively soon.\"\n\nThe minutes' release coincided with Wednesday's collapse of White House business advisory councils, which were scrapped by President Trump in the wake of several high-profile resignations following his comments on a white supremacist rally in Virginia that turned violent.\n\nThe two events sent the US dollar tumbling on exchange markets, with the Dollar Index losing 0.3 percent over the prior day's close shortly after 1900 GMT (3 a.m. Thursday in Manila).\n\n\"The Fed's growing concern about low inflation suggests officials would proceed cautiously in raising borrowing rates in the months ahead which could potentially scupper plans to hike again before year-end,\" Joe Manimbo of Western Union Business Solutions said in a research note.\n\n\u00a9 Agence France-Presse", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services", "wgt": 100, "id": 100, "label": {"sim": 0.6823529601097107, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9590887", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "freemalaysiatoday.com", "title": "Free Malaysia Today", "id": "10786"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://s3media.freemalaysiatoday.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/federal-reserve.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 558, "dateEnd": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "textEnd": 568, "date": "2017-07-25", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/world/2017/08/17/us-can-be-patient-in-raising-rates-fed-members-say/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:56:00", "title": "US can 'be patient' in raising rates, Fed members say", "uri": "710618469", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T00:56:00Z", "time": "00:56:00", "body": "Amid steady job creation and the falling jobless rate, the Fed has dismissed weak price pressures, blaming them on one-off \"transitory\" and \"idiosyncratic\" factors, such as falling mobile phone plan and medication prices.\n\nNEW YORK: US central bankers remain divided over inflation risks, and some argue they can afford to \"be patient\" before raising rates again, according to the minutes of the last policy meeting released Wednesday.\n\nThe Federal Reserve had been expected to raise the benchmark lending rate a third time this year, but the minutes of the July 25-26 meeting showed policymakers remained befuddled by weak inflation, despite historically low unemployment.\n\nThe minutes indicated the Fed could announce \"relatively soon\" the start of efforts to reduce the central bank's multi-trillion-dollar investment holdings.\n\nThey also showed Fed some members increasingly believed an era of inflation was settling in for the long haul, leaving policymakers increasingly torn in different directions.\n\nAmid steady job creation and the falling jobless rate, the Fed has dismissed weak price pressures, blaming them on one-off \"transitory\" and \"idiosyncratic\" factors, such as falling mobile phone plan and medication prices.\n\nBut after raising rates twice this year, with a third increase expected before the end of 2017, policymakers have found themselves hard pressed to explain the absence of inflation. Over the second quarter, inflation measures have remained weak or even retreated.\n\nOn one hand, some meeting participants feared that persistently low interest rates could create financial instability and spur risk taking. Others believed the low inflation justified allowing the economy to run hotter before hiking again.\n\nAs a group, Fed members generally believe inflation will remain low through the second half of 2017, with many believing it will stabilize \"over the next couple of years from its current low,\" according to the minutes.\n\n\"Many participants, however, saw some likelihood that inflation might remain below two percent for longer than they currently expected, and several indicated that risks to the inflation outlook could be tilted to the downside,\" the minutes said.\n\nThe dollar nosedives\n\nThose pointing to low inflation said the central bank should \"be patient\" before adopting its next rate hike \"until incoming information confirmed that the recent low readings on inflation were not likely to persist.\"\n\nFed members were again concerned by the dizzying heights to which Wall Street has risen since President Trump prevailed in November's presidential elections, suggesting too much easy money had encouraged market speculators.\n\n\"The staff warning about asset prices is hawkish, but the doves carried the day in July,\" Chris Low of FTN Financial said in a client note.\n\nThe minutes also suggested that as soon as its next meeting in September the central bank could announce the start of a process of drawing down its $4.5 trillion asset holdings, ending a stimulus policy put in place after the 2008 financial crisis.\n\nSince then, the Fed has used the returns on investments in government bonds to purchase yet more bonds but policymakers decided earlier this year the time was ripe for the policy to come to an end.\n\nFed members generally agreed that, given their belief the US economy would likely continue its economic recovery, \"it was appropriate to signal that implementation of the program likely would begin relatively soon.\"\n\nThe minutes' release coincided with Wednesday's collapse of White House business advisory councils, which were scrapped by President Trump in the wake of several high-profile resignations following his comments on a white supremacist rally in Virginia that turned violent.\n\nThe two events sent the US dollar tumbling on exchange markets, with the Dollar Index losing 0.3 percent over the prior day's close shortly after 1900 GMT.\n\n\"The Fed's growing concern about low inflation suggests officials would proceed cautiously in raising borrowing rates in the months ahead which could potentially scupper plans to hike again before year-end,\" Joe Manimbo of Western Union Business Solutions said in a research note.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Financial_Services", "wgt": 100, "id": 100, "label": "dmoz/Business/Financial Services"}, {"uri": {"sim": 0.6666666865348816, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "id": "9158996", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "title": "Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "id": "872"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Dudley"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "http://www.staradvertiser.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/web1_AP_17226475310079-300x207.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 2557, "textEnd": 2564, "date": "2017-07-26", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.staradvertiser.com/2017/08/14/business/feds-dudley-remains-in-favor-of-rate-hike/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:46:00", "title": "Fed's Dudley remains in favor of rate hike", "uri": "709436073", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T20:46:00Z", "time": "20:46:00", "body": "William C. Dudley, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, speaks during a panel discussion at The Bank of England in London in March.\n\nFederal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley said it isn't unreasonable to expect the central bank to announce plans in September to start trimming its balance sheet and said he supports another interest-rate increase this year if the economy evolves as he expects.\n\n\"I would expect -- I would be in favor of doing another rate hike later this year\" if the economy holds up, Dudley told the Associated Press.\n\nExpectations for a September announcement on when the Fed will begin to wind down its balance sheet weren't \"unreasonable,\" he said. A political debate over the debt ceiling is unlikely to have a \"big impact\" on that timetable because the central bank could announce the start of the program but delay the actual date.\n\n\"The plan is out there. It's been, I think, generally well-received, and fully anticipated,\" Dudley said of the outline for drawing down the $4.5 trillion balance sheet. \"In the last FOMC statement, we said that we expected this to happen relatively soon. So, I expect it to happen relatively soon.\"\n\nDudley's comments signal optimism at a time when inflation remains below the Fed's goal even as the labor market continues to expand and the overall economy is chugging along. The New York Fed chief brushed aside recent weak price data as a trend that will probably reverse, suggesting officials might be willing to look past the slowdown even as it becomes more sustained.\n\n\"QUITE A BIT TIGHTER\"\n\n\"We do expect as the labor market continues to tighten, to see firmer wage gains and that will ultimately filter into inflation moving up towards our 2 percent objective,\" Dudley said. \"A pretty broad range of evidence that suggests the labor market is quite a bit tighter than it's been in many years. Which is a good thing.\"\n\nFed officials have been projecting one more rate increase in 2017, for a total of three this year, but weak price gains have made markets doubt that outlook. Investors are pricing in just a 29 percent chance of a rate increase by year-end.\n\nThe U.S. has seen an extended run of sub-par inflation prints, the July Consumer Price Index reading showed last week. The Fed's preferred gauge, which comes out with a longer delay, was running at 1.4 percent in June -- well below the Fed's 2 percent goal.\n\nStill, Dudley's comments jibe with the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee's post-meeting statement on July 26, which said price gains were expected to \"stabilize around the Committee's 2 percent objective over the medium term.\" The Fed is scheduled to release minutes from that meeting this week, an account that could give a more textured glimpse into the inflation discussion.\n\n\"The jury's out of whether there is sort of structural, secular changes in place that are holding inflation lower on a sustained basis,\" Dudley said. \"The next four to six months I think are going to be important to see whether the readings that we've had over the last few months are mainly due to one-off factors, such as the big decline that we've seen in cellphone prices, or whether there's something more fundamental going on.\"\n\nWAGES, PRICES\n\nDudley said if secular forces are pushing inflation lower, it's possible that the unemployment rate could fall further before it precipitates higher wages and prices.\n\nThe jobless rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, down from 4.7 percent headed into the year and below policy makers' estimate of the longer-run sustainable rate. The median official expected U.S. joblessness to average 4.3 percent in the fourth quarter and hold around 4.6 percent in the longer term, according to quarterly projections updated in June.\n\nThe New York Fed chief also brushed aside concerns about high asset prices, saying he's \"not particularly concerned,\" primarily because \"asset prices are pretty consistent with what we're seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy.\" When asked about his impression of White House economic adviser Gary Cohn as Fed chairman, he said \"I don't want to evaluate the various candidates for the Federal Reserve, except to say that I think Gary is a reasonable candidate.\"\n\nDudley, 64, has been President of the New York Fed since 2009 and was formerly chief U.S. economist at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. He holds a Ph.D. in economics from the University of California Berkeley.", "date": "2017-08-14", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Economic", "wgt": 100, "id": 108, "label": It's been, I think, generally well-received, and fully anticipated,\" Dudley said of the outline for drawing down the $4.5 trillion balance sheet. \"In the last FOMC statement, we said that we expected this to happen relatively soon. Which is a good thing.\"\n\nFed officials have been projecting one more rate increase in 2017, for a total of three this year, but weak price gains have made markets doubt that outlook. Investors are pricing in just a 29 percent chance of a rate increase by year-end.\n\nThe U.S. has seen an extended run of sub-par inflation prints, the July Consumer Price Index reading showed last week. The Fed's preferred gauge, which comes out with a longer delay, was running at 1.4 percent in June -- well below the Fed's 2 percent goal.\n\nStill, Dudley's comments jibe with the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee's post-meeting statement on July 26, which said price gains were expected to \"stabilize around the Committee's 2 percent objective over the medium term.\" The Fed is scheduled to release minutes from that meeting this week, an account that could give a more textured glimpse into the inflation discussion.\n\n\"The jury's out of whether there is sort of structural, secular changes in place that are holding inflation lower on a sustained basis,\" Dudley said. \"The next four to six months I think are going to be important to see whether the readings that we've had over the last few months are mainly due to one-off factors, such as the big decline that we've seen in cellphone prices, or whether there's something more fundamental going on.\"\n\nWages, Prices\n\nDudley said if secular forces are pushing inflation lower, it's possible that the unemployment rate could fall further before it precipitates higher wages and prices.\n\nThe jobless rate fell to 4.3 percent in July, down from 4.7 percent headed into the year and below policy makers' estimate of the longer-run sustainable rate. The median official expected U.S. joblessness to average 4.3 percent in the fourth quarter and hold around 4.6 percent in the longer term, according to quarterly projections updated in June.\n\nThe New York Fed chief also brushed aside concerns about high asset prices, saying he's \"not particularly concerned,\" primarily because \"asset prices are pretty consistent with what we're seeing in terms of the actual performance of the economy.\" When asked about his impression of White House economic adviser Gary Cohn as Fed chairman, he said \"I don't want to evaluate the various candidates for the Federal Reserve, except to say that I think Gary is a reasonable candidate.\"\n\nDudley, 64, has been President of the New York Fed since 2009 and was formerly chief U.S. economist at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. {"sim": 0.658823549747467, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3361340", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9538807", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "cnbc.com", "title": "CNBC", "id": "722"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3361340", "image": "https://fm.cnbc.com/applications/cnbc.com/resources/img/editorial/2017/06/14/104530032-GettyImages-696002982-janet-yellen.1910x1000.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 132, "textEnd": 145, "date": "2017-06-14", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.cnbc.com/2017/08/16/fed-minutes-fed-split-over-path-of-rate-hikes.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:06:00", "title": "Fed minutes: Fed split over path of rate hikes", "uri": "710473658", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T18:06:00Z", "time": "18:06:00", "body": "Federal Reserve Board Chairwoman Janet Yellen arrives at a news conference following a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee June 14, 2017 in Washington, DC.\n\nA fissure appears to be developing at the Federal Reserve over when to raise interest rates: One side is preaching caution in a low-inflation environment while another worries over the price of delaying.\n\nThe divide appeared in minutes released from the Federal Open Market Committee's July meeting, when central bank policymakers voted to hold the target rate in a range of 1 percent to 1.25 percent. The summary portrays views that inflation ultimately will get to the Fed's 2 percent target but is clearly not there yet.\n\n\"Some participants\" who counseled patience expressed \"concern about the recent decline in inflation\" and said the Fed \"could afford to be patient under current circumstances.\" They \"argued against additional adjustments\" until the Fed was sure that inflation was on track.\n\nOn the other side, more hawkish members \"worried about risks arising from a labor market that had already reached full employment and was projected to tighten further.\" Backing off from a steady diet of rate hikes could cause the Fed to overshoot its employment target and cause financial instability, they said.\n\nHowever, it's been inflation where the Fed has continued to miss its target. Chair Janet Yellen's preferred measure, the core personal consumption expenditures index, most recently showed a 1.5 percent annualized gain. That has raised concerns over why the Fed is hiking when it remains considerably beneath its objectives.\n\nOne area that seemed to draw strong consensus was in the plan to reduce the Fed's $4.5 trillion \"balance sheet\" of bonds it accrued during three rounds of stimulus that began during the financial crisis.\n\nMembers agreed that the process of reducing the balance sheet should begin \"relatively soon,\" with some members arguing for a more concreate date to be set. Fed watchers largely expect the central bank to announce the roll-off to be announced at the September meeting and begin shortly thereafter.\n\nUnder the program, the Fed will set a cap for how much of the proceeds it receives will roll off each month, and then continue to reinvest the rest.\n\nThe disagreement over how quickly to raise rates comes at a critical time for the U.S. economy. Fed officials largely judge the economy strong enough to withstand gradual hikes and the slow-motion balance sheet rolloff, but some economists worry the Fed has waited too long and risks causing a recession.\n\nIn their assessment of the economy, FOMC members gave it largely positive remarks, particularly in the areas of employment and household spending. However, the minutes reflect concern over June's weak retail sales and the continuing lack of significant wage increases.\n\nOfficials also are less optimistic over getting help from fiscal policy. President Donald Trump's hopes for tax reform and infrastructure spending remain in limbo and had formed the basis for hopes that Washington would begin doing its part to accelerate growth.\n\n\"Several participants noted that uncertainty about the course of federal government policy, including in the areas of fiscal policy, trade, and health care, was tending to weigh down firms' spending and hiring plans,\" the minutes stated. \"In addition, a few participants suggested that the likelihood of near-term enactment of a fiscal stimulus program had declined further or that the fiscal stimulus likely would be smaller than they previously expected.\"\n\nThe FOMC meets next in September. Traders in the fed funds futures market assign virtually no chance to a rate hike then and about a 50 percent chance of a move before the end of the year.", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": The central bank has already disclosed that it will begin by dropping as much as $6 billion in government bonds and $4 billion in mortgage-backed securities every month.\n\nAccording to the minutes, participants generally agreed that it was \"appropriate to signal that implementation of the program likely would begin relatively soon, absent significant adverse developments in the economy or in financial markets.\"\n\nThere were some participants who wanted to kick off a balance sheet reduction at the July meeting, though most opted to stay the current course.\n\nOn the issue of rate hikes, Fed members were more divided. Some Fed watchers say the central bank could choose to wait until 2018 before raising interest rates, despite predictions for a December hike. Delaying the move could allow the Fed to further evaluate the pace of inflation, which has trailed the Fed's 2% target.\n\nWhile most members saw the outlook for the U.S. economy and labor market as little changed, others \"expressed concern about the recent decline in inflation.\" Those participants also said the Fed can be patient and wait until it becomes clear that recent low readings on inflation were merely a hiccup.\n\nLow inflation \"causes indigestion for the nation's central bankers,\" said Mark Hamrick, senior economic analyst at Bankrate.com. \"It stands in the way of their long-term hope to boost interest rates and get on with the business of shrinking the $4 trillion balance sheet. Even so, it appears we'll hear about the planned timing of so-called quantitative tightening at the September FOMC meeting.\"\n\nCharles Evans, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, recently indicated that a potential rate hike in December is not set in stone. New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley said he would support a December increase to the federal funds rate if economic conditions remain strong.\n\nFed members reiterated their intent to move \"gradually\" as they normalize interest rates.
